HEADLINE: Seeing the Futures 

BYLINE:  By Philip Bobbitt; Philip Bobbitt, author of "The Shield of Achilles: War, Peace and the Course of History," is a law professor at the University of Texas and a former senior director at the National Security Council.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex. 

 BODY:
There is a good deal of criticism these days leveled at the Bush administration for being surprised by a number of events -- not just the Sept. 11 attacks, but also the escape and regrouping of the Al Qaeda and Taliban leadership after the Afghanistan war, French intransigence at the United Nations in the build up to the Iraq war, Turkey's refusal of timely cooperation before that invasion, the coordinated murder and sabotagecampaign led by Baath Party remnants in Iraq, and the widespread mood of Iraqi impatience with the American presence there. 
 So the question is: was the administration blindsided because of poor work by the intelligence services, or was the problem poor coordination by the National Security Council, which is supposed to integrate the various intelligence, diplomatic and defense agencies? 
 Actually, the answer is that none of these events was really a surprise. Everything that appeared to catch the White House off guard had been anticipated in various reports, some by the National Security Council itself. The problem wasn't foresight but forethought: the Bush administration, like the Clinton White House before it, has yet to come up with an effective process to marshal judgment on the events it does foresee. 
This is not really the fault of the National Security Council. Rather, it is a matter of the historic changes around the world and of the habits of organizing ourselves we inherited from the cold war. For nearly 50 years, American decision-makers could rely on forms of "strategic planning" -- a method that begins with choosing a desired result and then plotting the decisions that will have to be made to reach that goal. Strategic planning worked well in the two-power world because we were able to extrapolate from a relatively stable and familiar security environment, relying on more or less agreed-upon intelligence estimates. Governments sought the likeliest linear future, and planned accordingly.
Unfortunately, in an increasingly decentralized world, in which previously insignificant actors and factors can play a decisive role, strategic planning can leave decision-makers flat-footed. In its unidimensional reliance on a single future, strategic planning hardens the "official future" agencies internalize, and thus prepares them poorly for appreciating rapid changes in circumstance and for making agile adaptations.
For example, using strategic thinking it might have been estimated last year that Saddam Hussein could not have produced nuclear weapons in the less than seven years since his rudimentary programs were halted in 1995. In the new world, however, no one could make such a judgment with confidence -- not because we don't know how long it takes to develop nuclear processing plants or how much fissile material is required, but because we couldn't know whether Iraq might have bought a nuclear device on the clandestine market and become a nuclear power in an afternoon.
This is why strategic planning was largely abandoned by the Clinton administration, in which I served. But no new way of thinking has replaced it. It is an open secret that the National Security Council's strategic planning directorate is really devoted to communications tasks, and that the State Department's policy planning staff is actually a speechwriting office.
In this new era of uncertainty, not only must we must accept that simple forecasting is not going to be very useful to us, we must sharpen our skills of forethought. One way will be to augment traditional strategic planning with "scenario planning," a strategy that has long been a staple at the largest multinational corporations. Scenario planning involves the creation of alternative narratives about the future based on different decisions -- by many players -- as each scenario progresses. 
As opposed to the classic strategic method of applying the past to the future -- coming up with a single, likeliest story about how things will turn out -- scenario planning is about applying the futureto the present, creating a learning framework for decisions. The idea is not so much to predict the future as to consider the forces that will push the future along different paths, in order to help leaders recognize new possibilities, assess new threats and make decisions that reach much further into the future. 
Scenario planning can also exploit the changes under way in intelligence collection -- especially the greater emphasis on human sources. Unlike strategic planning, which tends to rely on quantitative and technical information like population figures and productivity reports, scenario planning tends to use more qualitative and dynamic data. It depends in large part on studying economic, political and social trends. 
Scenario planning at Royal Dutch Shell, where I am a senior adviser, helped the corporation become one of the most profitable oil conglomerates. In the early 1970's, its scenario planners worked on hypothetical futures involving an oil boycott against the West; when political events finally brought about the Arab oil crisis, the company not only wasn't taken by surprise, it was in a position to capitalize. In the 1990's Shell analysts were scenario-planning a potential backlash against global companies, long before the antiglobalization movement took off. Thus, while most companies reacted to the new movement with corporate disdain, Shell was courting nongovernmental groups and decentralizing its global operations so that decisions in foreign divisions could be made by people living in and sensitive to the countries affected.
Getting the government to emphasize scenario planning will not be easy. To be successful, the approach depends on well-organized dialogue between decision makers at many levels, which would be culture shock for the rigidly hierarchical executive branch. (Indeed, despite the efforts of advocates like Joseph Nye, dean of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, to get Washington interested in scenario planning, only one country, Singapore, has made extensive use of the practice.) Our various national security agencies may not be competitive businesses, but they often behave toward each other as if they were. Intelligence is often "stovepiped" -- when analysts refuse to share information and sources with interagency rivals working on the same problems -- and mutually distrustful cultures abound. 
Also, scenario planning requires a political culture that is tolerant of uncertainty. Contingencies of uncertain probability tend to be of little interest to politicians, who are confident they know the future. Similarly, competing scenarios are anathema to bureaucrats whose careers are threatened by answering questions like, "What would it take for this estimate to be dramatically wrong?" -- which translates to, "What arguments can you give me that undermine your own recommendations?" 
To change this culture, we need an interagency working group that can organize scenario planning for a new era. It should be headed by the senior director for strategic planning at the National Security Council, and should include the director of policy planning at the State Department, the chairman of the National Intelligence Council, the political-military director for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the assistant secretary of Defense for strategic and threat reduction, and a senior representative of the Treasury secretary. This body would be charged with coordinating the work and circulating the results of scenario planning by a team made up of veteran government analysts and, perhaps, experienced people from the private sector. 
The Bush administration came to office promising to bring the best practices of the business world to bear on government. In many areas it has. Scenario planning at the National Security Council should be added to the list.

HEADLINE: The Great Divide: The U.S. and Europe Stretch to Close It 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
After months of acrimony, Europe and the United States are modulating their tone and struggling to work more cooperatively on the divisive issues of Iraq, Afghanistan and European defense cooperation.
 The conciliatory stance on the American side is motivated at least in part by the urgent need to have NATO countries contribute more troops and money to Iraq and to deliver promised and much needed troops and equipment to Afghanistan. But there is a universal recognition among NATO members that the rift both within the Atlantic alliance and between Europe and the United States has to be repaired if the alliance is to remain viable. 
 "I won't say everybody is pretending that everything is fine, but people are really trying to be more constructive, less emotional and, well, diplomatic," said one senior NATO military official who took part in meetings of the group's defense and foreign ministers in Brussels last week. 
The most obvious evidence of the new tone was the public posture of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld at the alliance defense ministers' meeting last week.
"Maybe we ought to try to do a better job of communicating," he said at one point, much to the surprise of European defense ministers and military officers.
When reporters asked him about a European Union plan for defense cooperation separate from the Atlantic alliance, he did not repeat his past criticisms, but ducked the question.
"You're egging me on. You're trying to get me in trouble," he said, virtually admitting he was under instructions to hold his fire. He added, "I'm plucky but I'm not stupid."
Instead, Mr. Rumsfeld praised the Europeans for developing military capacity that they could deploy rapidly in emergencies.
More surprisingly, perhaps, he did not criticize France and Germany, the two most important American allies who opposed the Iraq war, for refusing to send troops or give financial support to help stabilize Iraq.
Mr. Rumsfeld's message was followed later in the week by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's call to NATO at its foreign ministers meeting to consider expanding its role in Iraq, a clear admission that the United States needs to internationalize its Iraq mission if it is to succeed. No one embraced the idea, but no one said no.
"That was a sea change -- that there wasn't the derision and hostility toward the U.S. on Iraq that's been here since the beginning of the year," said one senior official who attended the meetings.
Finally, on Afghanistan, suggestions by both Mr. Rumsfeld and Mr. Powell that the United States would like the alliance to assume more responsibility, perhaps eventually taking over the entire American-led operation, would not only put more of a burden on the Europeans but would also underscore the centrality of the alliance.
On the European side, even President Jacques Chirac of France, the staunchest opponent of the Iraq war effort, is looking for ways to play a more active role in the Atlantic alliance and even in Iraq.
In a 90-minute meeting last week with Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Chirac laid out situations in which France might be willing to help out in Iraq, according to an official familiar with the meeting.
Mr. Biden declined to comment on the substance of his conversation with Mr. Chirac, but confirmed in an interview that Mr. Chirac was seeking ways to repair the relationship with Washington.
Mr. Chirac also told Mr. Biden that France had requested the appointment of two French one-star generals to NATO's command structure, one at the alliance headquarters in Mons, Belgium, the other in Norfolk, Va., as a sign of willingness to work more closely with Washington on security matters.
"This is a time to be grown up, show a little sophistication," Mr. Biden said in Brussels last week, in urging the Bush administration to accept France's request.
Although France is not part of the military command of NATO, it has the second largest contingent in the alliance's new rapid response force, which was inaugurated in October to respond quickly to long-range crisis missions. In Afghanistan, American and French soldiers are training the new Afghan Army, and American and French Special Forces conduct joint antiterrorist operations near the Pakistani border.
A senior NATO military officer confirmed the French request but said it was uncertain whether the Pentagon would approve any move that would appear France-friendly.
For their part, the American armed forces consider the French military the most expeditionary army in Europe, and are eager to expand military cooperation in the alliance, the officer added. France still has a contingency plan on the shelf to send 8,000 to 10,000 troops to Iraq under the right political circumstances, senior NATO officials said.
Concerning a European defense identity, the Europeans have abandoned a plan to create a European Union military headquarters in Tervuren, Belgium, that would be separate from NATO. European Union foreign ministers agreed at their recent meeting in Naples, Italy, to create a small operational planning unit in the existing European Union military staff headquarters instead.
That move followed an agreement among Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, Mr. Chirac and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder that the European Union be allowed to plan and run its own military operations.
In its deal with France and Germany, Britain won assurances that a European Union military operation without NATO participation would be a remote possibility.
Even if a European Union military mission were planned and operated from a European Union center, it would be subject to a veto by any union member, British officials said.
Despite deep divisions within the British government on how tightly to embrace France and Germany on European defense, Mr. Blair is convinced that by joining them he has been able to help shape the debate and that he can control the outcome in a way that will be acceptable to Washington.
Mr. Blair and President Bush have consulted by phone about the plan, and Mr. Bush has said publicly that he believes that Mr. Blair "will be true to his word" that the plan will not undermine the alliance.
According to some diplomats, as a result of his communication with Mr. Blair, Mr. Bush persuaded Mr. Rumsfeld to say nothing hostile about the European defense plan at the NATO meetings, especially in public.
When asked about European defense in Brussels last week, for example, Mr. Rumsfeld admitted that the issue was "above my pay grade at this stage." He added that it would be "wrestled with" at the highest levels.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Origins of Rogue Software May Be Undetectable
The people who design rogue programs that take over computers from afar are now applying the tactic that made music pirating programs so effective.
 The rogue programs, known as "Trojan horses," have enabled pornographers and others to mask their identities by using unwitting people's computers as relay stations. It had been assumed that diligent investigators could ultimately trace such material by identifying the server computer used as a starting point. But now a researcher has determined that a new kind of Trojan horse could make this system virtually unstoppable. Page C2. 

Growth Pains for Spanish Concern
Spain's largest media conglomerate, Grupo Prisa, is expanding into Latin and North America, but not without significant challenges. For one, its competitors have deep pockets. In the United States, Prisa was recently outbid by Multicultural Broadcasting of New York for control of Radio Unica. Moreover, because of currency fluctuations, its revenue has shrunk. C9.

Accepting Later Online Orders
Online merchants are poised to live dangerously this holiday season, offering to accept orders later in the shopping cycle than in the past while still promising to deliver the goods by Christmas Day. Many are accepting orders as late as Dec. 18 for standard ground shipping, and as late as Dec. 23 for expedited service. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C8.

A New Chip-Making Technique
I.B.M. plans today to describe successful efforts to create silicon memory chips using a new nanoscale technique. The technique uses a template provided by a plastic polymer that organizes itself naturally. The approach has enabled I.B.M. to create chips with memory cells just 20 nanometers in diameter and 40 nanometers apart. The approach could make data more secure, I.B.M. said. C3.

Dell's recent decision to direct some customer service calls to help desks in the United States, rather than to its call center in Bangalore, India, shows how companies with support operations overseas are having to tread a fine line with their clients. New Economy. C4.

Move to CD-DVD's on Single Disc
One Disc Technologies of Dallas is in talks with major and independent music labels to begin manufacturing a combination single-disc product that plays DVD video on one side and CD audio on the other, James Wilson, the company's president, said. C6.

Way to Print Detailed ID Photos
A subsidiary of DuPont and A4Vision, a start-up company, are to announce today a novel system for printing unusually clear and detailed three-dimensional photos on documents like passports. C4.

Wi-Fi as a Promotional Tool
Starbucks has been at the vanguard of offering wireless Internet access in the popular Wi-Fi format, with wireless "hot spots" in about 2,600 of its 4,100 stores in the United States as a way to encourage customers to come in, log on and hang out. But anticipating the day when Wi-Fi alone may not distinguish one retailer from another, Starbucks is experimenting with the equivalent of Wi-Fi flavors of the month. C4.

Haven't I Seen That Tie Before?
A Georgia inventor has been awarded a patent for an online system that lets people give away gifts they are set to receive that they do not want or need. Patents. C6.

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
Hear this, procrastinators. More online merchants say they can deliver the goods for last-minute shoppers.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
MADE bold by improved technology and shipping methods, online merchants are poised to live dangerously this holiday season, offering to accept orders later in the shopping cycle than in the past while still promising to deliver the goods by Christmas Day.
 Many are accepting orders as late as Dec. 18 for standard ground shipping, and as late as Dec. 23 for expedited service. 
 The willingness to work to tight deadlines indicates that the e-tailing industry thinks it has learned from its mistakes. After the 1999 holiday shopping season, the Federal Trade Commission fined six online merchants a total of $1.5 million for failing to keep delivery promises, and shoppers were understandably wary for the next few years. 
But last year online consumers shopped later in the holiday season than they had in 2001, and orders were rising for many retailers in the week before Christmas, according to Jupiter Research, an Internet consulting firm. Because online merchants generally succeeded in shipping those gifts on time, Patti Freeman Evans, a Jupiter analyst, predicts that consumers will rely on this year's late-shipping offers in even greater numbers.
"In the early years, people believed the Internet would be great for last-minute shopping," Ms. Evans said. "Unfortunately, it wasn't all that fast. But now, it's getting there."
Ms. Evans said that in a recent survey of more than 100 online retail executives, only 15 percent said they would not allow customers to order after Dec. 20 for Christmas delivery using express service. Last year nearly a third of the respondents to a similar survey set Dec. 20 as the cut-off date for express service. 
Significant investments in shipping operations are responsible for the new confidence. About 60 percent of the executives surveyed said they had improved both their Web site technology and their shipping and handling operations in the last year, Ms. Evans said. More than half had shored up their call center operations.
Sharper Image is one of the newly emboldened. The company, which sells consumer electronics and other items through its Web site and catalog and in stores, said it had spent $3 million to $5 million last year to upgrade its San Francisco warehouse and build a new one in Richmond, Va., to augment its main warehouse in Little Rock, Ark.
Because of the geographical reach of these three warehouses, the company can offer two-day shipping to its Internet and catalog customers on about 20 percent more orders this year than last, Sharper Image's president, Tracy Y. Wan, said.
The company also significantly revamped its computer systems to allow orders to be sent more frequently to the warehouses during the day. In the past, she said, warehouse employees could process orders only at less frequent intervals; as a result, large batches could spill over into the next day. 
"You're able to reach great economies of scale when you reach over $600 million in business," Ms. Wan said, referring to this year's projected sales for Sharper Image, online and offline. "You can justify multiple distribution centers."
Ms. Wan noted that a nimbler last-minute shipping capacity would be particularly crucial this season, because Hanukkah begins on Dec. 20, nearly three weeks later than last year. "With that shift," Ms. Wan said, "there'll be some huge days coming up." 
Other retailers describe similar improvements in shipping. Jeff Wilke, Amazon.com's senior vice president for worldwide operations, said the company had reduced its processing and delivery times. 
Mr. Wilke, who answered a reporter's questions via e-mail, declined to quantify that improvement, but he said most of the progress had come from "getting each package to the dock at the right time and ready to load on the right truck." 
"We continue to work, worldwide, with each of our carriers," he wrote, "to reduce the mean and variation in their delivery times."
Online retail executives said their operational adjustments had led to new marketing strategies, as well. "For the first time, we're expecting to promote hard, right up to the last minute," said Ken Seiff, the chief executive of the discount apparel retailer Bluefly.com.
Mr. Seiff said that in previous years it was typical for the Web site to upgrade a customer's shipping request without the customer's knowledge -- to an air delivery, say, when the customer had paid only for ground shipment -- "because it was taking several days just to pack and ship, and we wanted to make sure the shipping period was reasonable."
Now, Mr. Seiff said, more than 99 percent of Bluefly's orders are shipped within 24 hours of the customer's order.
As a result, Bluefly will be able to avoid paying for shipping upgrades for customers this year, freeing the company to pursue last-minute shoppers without diminishing profits.
That is no small consideration, because 11th-hour shoppers tend to spend more. According to a recent poll by RoperASW, a research firm, 65 percent of consumers who characterized themselves as last-minute shoppers said they tended to spend more than they had budgeted. (Late shoppers are also usually male, according to retail executives.)
Because retailers have stocked rather leanly this year, after having had to resort to steep discounting during the 2002 holiday seasonto clear their shelves, procrastinating shoppers may find themselves having to move up the price curve to find items still available, executives said. 
"Most retailers have kept inventories a lot tighter this year," said Alison L. May, chief executive of RedEnvelope.com, an online and catalog gifts retailer.
With potentially more online shoppers showing up late to select from limited supplies, accurate inventory tracking systems will be important. In past years, many consumers complained that they had ordered an item only to be notified by e-mail later in the day that the item was out of stock.
Ms. Evans, the Jupiter analyst, says that fewer than 40 percent of online retailers have real-time inventory systems that allow them to quickly remove sold-out items from their Web listings.
Although RedEnvelope's inventory system is not continuously updated, Ms. May said that it did check inventory hourly and that it pulled items from its Web pages when supplies dropped below a designated threshold. That technique, she said, virtually eliminates the possibility that customers will order products that turn out to be unavailable. 
Like many other online merchants, RedEnvelope plans to sell later into the holiday season this year. The company guarantees Christmas delivery for orders placed through Dec. 17 -- two days later than last year. 
The company, originally named 911Gifts.com, has always pitched itself as a last-minute gift specialist. But RedEnvelope's operations have grown more complex, Ms. May said. 
Earlier this year, the company took over management of its shipping warehouse -- a task previously handled by a contractor. RedEnvelope also buys more items from overseas than in the past, and it personalizes more items for consumers, as well. 
"All of that adds a different dimension to things," Ms. May said. "But still, at the same time, we've gotten a little bit better." 
And, she and many other e-tailers are betting this season, a little bit quicker.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Companies sending work abroad are learning cultural sensitivity -- to their American customers.

BYLINE:  By Laurie J. Flynn 

 BODY:
DELL'S recent decision to direct some customer service calls to help desks in the United States, rather than to its call center in Bangalore, India, shows how companies with customer support operations overseas are having to tread a fine line with their clients, some of whom are still surprised to talk to technicians on a different continent. 
 To analysts and consultants, the outsourcing of technology jobs is a trend that will only grow. In Dell's case, some of its most coveted business customers complained to management that Indian technical support workers relied too heavily on scripted answers and were unable to handle more complex computer problems. While most questions phoned in by home computer users tend to be fairly straightforward -- like how to update software or install a wireless adaptor -- greater expertise is needed to respond to corporate network problems. 
 A spokesman for Dell, Barry French, said the company was responding to concerns from business customers when it decided last month to route calls from many largebusiness customers to American call centers, though he maintained that it would not be sending fewer calls over all to its operation in India. 
"We just flipped a switch," he said, explaining that some consumer calls that had been handled by domestic call centers would now be sent to India. 
"What companies are finding is that offshore can be good for generic, commodity services," said Howard Rubin, executive vice president of the Meta Group Inc., a consulting firm. "Corporate customers have problems very local to their applications and very specific to their companies."
Analysts say that along with skill considerations, some companies may be worried about criticism from labor groups and some customers who object to sending jobs overseas. Governments are under particular pressure. This year, half a dozen states are considering that workers hired under state contracts be American citizens or documented workers. 
Stephen Lane, research vice president for information technology services at the Aberdeen Group in Boston, said, "There is a backlash and it's building, particularly in sectors like information technology that is still being hard hit by the economy." 
Clearly, information technology workers will face more difficulty as technology jobs move to cheaper labor markets abroad. According to a new survey by IDC, a market research company, nearly a quarter of information technology services will be sent offshore by 2007, sharply higher than the 5 percent of technology services being handled offshore this year. 
The first wave of offshore outsourcing began with the movement of customer-service call work to offices in India, Malaysia and Indonesia, but American companies are also beginning to send back-office work, like the processing of forms, abroad as well.
While the outsourcing of technical service jobs is reminiscent of the movement of manufacturing jobs overseas in recent decades, analysts say the difference is that the change in the technology industries is occurring faster. And the jobs that are beginning to leave are considered white-collar jobs that have traditionally been protected from competition with foreign workers. 
"Companies are getting more aggressive about it," said Chris Disher, an outsourcing specialist with the consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton. "The economies are straightforward -- you get an $80,000 engineer for $12,000," he said, alluding to wages in India.
The challenge for the United States technology companies, according to industry consultants, is to distinguish between the tasks that can be effectively handled offshore and those that cannot. Some, like Dell, have learned that they need to be sensitive to the reaction of their customers.
"In times like these, your business is attached to customer sentiment," said Atul Vashistha, chief executive of NeoIT, a California company that advises companies on outsourcing to India. "It's primarily a question of market timing."
"There are truly some areas where complexities" make sending work offshore difficult, Mr. Vashistha said. He recounted the experience of one client, a skateboard manufacturer with almost all its customers teenage boys, that found sending its support services overseas disastrous. The cultural nuances, and the constantly changing jargon of skateboarding, made it necessary for support calls to be handled by like-minded young American men. The company, which Mr. Vashistha declined to name, moved its support operations back to the United States last year.
By contrast, Scotiabank, a Canadian company, has kept its customer service operations in Canada, using technology to keep labor costs low. Higher customer satisfaction is worth the slightly higher cost, said John Parkinson, chief technologist for the Americas region at Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, a consulting business that works closely with the bank. 
Many offshore call centers are becoming more sensitive to the need to tutor workers in American customs as a crucial part of their training. Some workers in customer service jobs in Bangalore, for example, are being instructed to watch reruns of "Friends" to acquaint themselves with the cultural norms of American consumers, said Mr. Disher, the Booz Allen specialist. Trainees at many firms are also asked to read American newspapers and magazines, and are coached on American consumer habits. 
Still, many callers do not seem to care where the help desk is. "Most of the time, they're just happy to be talking to a human," Mr. Parkinson said. "The vast majority of people are indifferent to whether it's an American if they're getting good service."

HEADLINE: Will the Fed Stick to Its Plan On Low Rates? 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
The economy is growing much faster than expected and unemployment is edging down, but analysts do not expect the Federal Reserve to declare victory when its policy making committee meets Tuesday.
 Fed officials have made it clear that they see no need to raise the federal funds rate, which is the interest rate at which banks lend to each other overnight, any time soon. The rate is currently 1 percent, which is the lowest rate in 45 years. 
 The real question is whether the central bank will retreat from its open-ended commitment to keep rates low "for a considerable period." Retreating from that commitment would be a first step toward tightening monetary policy, putting markets on alert that rate increases are possible several months down the road. 
Fed officials have a number of reasons for wanting to wait before taking even that first step. Though the economy grew 8.2 percent in the third quarter and seems poised to grow at nearly 4 percent through next year, Fed officials have said they want to see significant improvement in the job market and more evidence that the specter of deflation, or declining prices, has been banished.
The unemployment data released last Friday provided evidence that the job market is improving, but more slowly than the economy as a whole. The Labor Department reported that the economy added 57,000 jobs in November. That is less than half the pace in August and September and well below the 250,000 jobs a month that economists say are necessary to bring a big reduction in employment.
Inflation, meanwhile, continues to climb at very low rates, and prices for a broad range of consumer goods are actually declining. Because the productivity of workers has been soaring all year, and shot up by 9.2 percent in the third quarter, the cost of labor has actually been declining.
Analysts are divided about whether the Fed will adjust its language. Laurence E. Meyer, a former Fed governor and now analyst at Macroeconomic Advisors, an economic analysis and forecasting company, predicted that the Fed would drop its commitment to keeping policy relaxed "for a considerable period."
But Mr. Meyer also predicted that the Fed would not actually raise rates until at least next June and probably not until January 2005.
Many other analysts predict that the Fed will either stick closely to its previous statements or change the language but not its message.
"I think the probability of a change is virtually zero," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo Bank. 
For months now, Fed officials have refused to budge from their position that the risk of unwanted inflation is lower than the risk of an undesirable decline in inflation. Although Fed officials have never said what they consider an acceptable rate of inflation, their statements suggest that they would be uncomfortable if it dipped below 1 percent.
Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, noted in a speech that inflation was running at an annual rate of about 1.25 percent and might decline further in the months ahead.
With unemployment hovering around 6 percent and factories running at less than three-quarters of full capacity, Mr. Parry predicted that "it's going to take more than a few months of robust growth to work off that that slack."
Mr. Parry acknowledged that the United States economy expanded by 8.2 percent in the third quarter of this year, the fastest growth in 20 years, but he also said that the risks of renewed inflation were much lower than in previous economic recoveries. "I believe there's still room for some pretty strong growth before the risk of inflationary pressures would become a primary concern."
In a speech last month, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, avoided using the phrase "a considerable period." But he went out of his way to say that inflationary pressures were low enough that monetary policy could afford to be "patient."
William C. Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman Sachs, said that the Federal Reserve might tweak the wording of its statement after Tuesday's meeting but would adhere to the same basic message.
"Fed officials want inflation to rise," Mr. Dudley wrote in a research note on Friday. "Until this occurs or seems imminent due to increased resource utilization, they are likely to keep the Federal funds rate target unchanged at 1 percent."

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
For Growth, Spanish Media Company Plans to Go West

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: MADRID, Dec. 1 

 BODY:
It had seemed like low-hanging fruit. 
 Back in the late 1990's, as Jesus de Polanco looked across the Atlantic he detected in the Americas a region ripe for the products and services of the Grupo Prisa. That is the publishing and broadcasting company he had built into Spain's largest media conglomerate, perhaps best known for the country's leading paper, El Pais. 
 After all, Prisa's publisher, Grupo Santillana, had been big in Latin America for decades. And to Mr. Polanco's eye, the United States' rapidly growing Hispanic population, with more disposable income than most people in Latin America, made North America an alluring business target. 
To raise cash for further expansion in the Americas, Mr. Polanco, the company's chairman, took Prisa public in 2000, with 30 percent of the company now trading among investors on the Madrid stock exchange. His nephew, Jaime Polanco, who is responsible for Prisa's international business, struck radio, movie and television deals in Latin America and North America. 
In the United States, Prisa owns an AM radio station in Miami, WSUA, and is involved in Spanish-language film and television production, in partnership with the Mexican company Grupo Televisa, and Univision, the American Spanish-language media giant. Such bustle led the Miami news magazine Poder to choose Jaime Polanco, now 40, international chief executive of the year in 2002.
But Prisa's new-world expansion has not been without snags. In Bolivia, where the company has fallen out with its local partner, the businessman Raul Garafulic, Prisa is looking to reduce its stake in radio, television and newspapers. In the United States, Prisa was outbid in October by Multicultural Radio Broadcasting of New York in its effort to buy stations from Radio Unica Communications, the No.3 Spanish-language radio chain, which is selling assets as part of a bankruptcy reorganization. 
Moreover, the growing strength of the euro has hurt Prisa's revenue from the Americas, after the money made in dollars and various Latin American currencies is converted. And as it strives to become an international player, Prisa faces competitors with deep pockets. Its major rival in Spain is the diversified media company Recoletos, which is involved in newspapers, magazines and television and is owned by the British publishing conglomerate Pearson. 
In the United States, it encounters the likes of Univision, which although a Prisa customer in film and television, is a daunting rival in radio, having spent $3.5 billon this year to acquire the biggest Spanish-language radio chain, Hispanic Broadcasting of Dallas. The second-largest Hispanic radio company, the Spanish Broadcasting System, is part of NBC's Telemundo and is owned by the General Electric Company. 
"There is strong competition," said Aida Levitan, president of the Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies and chairwoman of Publicis Sanchez & Levitan in Miami. 
Prisa's core businesses in Spain, which contribute the bulk of revenues, are sustaining the company, said Jaime Gortazar, an analyst at UBS Securities in Madrid. El Pais, with 445,500 circulation, is the country's largest paper. Prisa's chain of 420 Spanish radio stations, SER, leads the industry. And Prisa owns 19 percent of Sogecable, Spain's sole paid subscription digital service with several channels, whose crown jewel is soccer rights to popular teams like Real Madrid. These activities, along with magazines that include the Spanish edition of Rolling Stone, provide the cash flow that is crucial to Prisa's growth in Latin America.
In the first nine months of this year, Prisa's revenue rose 5 percent from the year-earlier period, to 988.7 million euros, or $1.19 billion. Net profit, however, dropped 44 percent, to 47.6 million euros, mainly from unfavorable currency conversions. Prisa executives say the company stands to benefit from growth in Spain's economy, which continues at double the rate of the rest of Europe. And if an economic revival in the United States spills into Latin America, they say, Prisa's business there could get a lift. 
"When the turnaround comes to Latin America, we have a competitive advantage," said Ignacio Santillana, 55, Prisa's chief operating officer. (The fact that his name is the same as the company's textbook unit, Grupo Santillana, is coincidental.) 
Mr. Santillana is one of the executives to whom the company's founder, Mr. Polanco -- now 74 -- has turned over most day-to-day operations. Other important officials are Polanco family members who have led the charge into Latin America. These include his Mr. Polanco's daughter, Isabel, who runs Grupo Santillana. Three years ago the unit acquired Editora Moderna, a publisher in Brazil, a country that now ranks with Mexico and Argentina among Grupo Santillana's biggest markets. 
"In underdeveloped countries, education is an important issue," Mr. Santillana said. "You don't have to be Latin to understand Latin America, but it helps."
Jaime Polanco widened Prisa's radio holdings in the Americas. Prisa now controls 87 percent of Grupo Latino de Radio, which owns 300 stations in Chile, Colombia, Panama and Costa Rica, as well as the Miami station. In Mexico, the company owns 50 percent of Radiopolis, the radio division of the media company Grupo Televisa. 
Mr. Santillana said Prisa's objective was to create a Hispanic radio group spanning the Americas, then float part of it on the stock market, perhaps as early as 2005. "The Latin American radio market is still very fragmented," he said.
And Prisa still sees the United States as the main chance. There, the Hispanic population has grown more than 60 percent in the last decade, to more than 35 million. 
But Ms. Levitan, the advertising executive in Miami, cautioned that Prisa could face challenges trying to use its Latin American beachhead as a departure point for the United States market. Big international media buying agencies like Carat, part of the Aegis Group, and Optimedia, part of Publicis, may welcome the prospect of a unified Hispanic market spanning the Americas, she said. But for most Hispanic advertising agencies in the United States, she said, "these are two separate markets -- at least for now."
Mr. Santillana says Prisa is spreading the financial burden of its overseas efforts by finding partners, like Mexico's Grupo Televisa for film and television and Julio Mario Santo Domingo, one of Colombia's wealthiest businessmen, for radio. Moreover, Prisa does not shy from discarding assets to reduce losses and raise cash. In October, the company cut its stake in a group of Spanish printing companies to 40 percent by selling a majority stake to the British company Polestar and a Spanish investment fund.
The expansion of Prisa's businesses through partnerships and acquisitions will continue, Mr. Santillana said, as Prisa keeps a close eye on its debt, which is currently 600 million euros ($725 million). Although the company has only about 50 million euros in cash, Mr. Santillana said, "We generate sufficient resources to self-finance." 
Still, Prisa's ambitious wish list prompts some analysts to wonder whether the company has sufficiently deep pockets to make it all come true. "At the end of the day, can they manage it?" asked Mr. Gortazar of UBS. "They have to invest an awful lot."

HEADLINE: Stalking the Giant Chicken Coop 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
On July 30, 1965, Lyndon Johnson flew to Independence, Mo., and in the presence of a smiling Harry Truman, signed the bill that created Medicare.
 "No longer will older Americans be denied the healing miracle of modern medicine," said Johnson. 
 The growls of opposition in the background were muted. Medicare was a desperately needed program, and it grew to be a wildly popular one. But conservatives were outraged by it. Socialized medicine, they snarled. Un-American. 
Truman had proposed a health care program for the elderly back in the 40's. It went nowhere. Jack Kennedy pushed it in the early 60's. Same result. It took Johnson's legislative genius and his enormous mandate from the 1964 presidential election to bring the program into being. And even then it wasn't easy.
Johnson's biographer, Robert Dallek, recalled that Ronald Reagan "saw Medicare as the advance wave of socialism, which would 'invade every area of freedom in this country.' "
"Reagan," wrote Mr. Dallek, "predicted that Medicare would compel Americans to spend their 'sunset years telling our children and our children's children what it was like in America when men were free.' "
Newt Gingrich ranted against Medicare in the 1990's, comparing its operations to "centralized command bureaucracies" in Moscow. And George W. Bush tried to fashion a prescription drug benefit that would require senior citizens to leave the traditional Medicare program before they could get the benefit.
After nearly four decades, during which Medicare significantly improved the health and economic conditions of the nation's elderly, this unrelenting hostility can fairly be called an obsession.
Today President Bush will sign into law a prescription drug benefit under Medicare that will introduce the first cold drafts of bitter reality to the G.O.P.'s long dream of dismantling Medicare as we've known it.
Think of Medicare as a giant chicken coop. Keep in mind that the hostile-to-Medicare Republicans control the presidency and both houses of Congress. Now you decide who the foxes and the chickens are. (Hint: we're not talking about spring chickens.)
When Lyndon Johnson and Harry Truman got together for the debut of Medicare, they were genuinely concerned about the medical needs of the nation's elderly. "These people," said Truman, "are our prideful responsibility and they are entitled, among other benefits, to the best medical protection available."
The bill that President Bush will sign today is a giant windfall for the drug companies, opening up a huge new market with virtually no effort to restrain prices. It will give Medicare recipients a modest drug benefit, but at a potentially dreadful cost. The bill starts the process of undermining Medicare by turning parts of it over to insurance companies, H.M.O.'s and other private contractors.
The drug benefit will be delivered almost entirely through private insurance plans. It would have been more efficient and cheaper to deliver it the same way other Medicare benefits are delivered. But that's not the idea. The Bush administration has mastered the art of legalized banditry, in which tons of government money -- the people's money -- are hijacked and handed over to the special interests.
Drug company stock prices soared with the passage of the Medicare bill, a sign that another government vault had been blown open and the big Medicare money was in play. The Republicans are not subtle about these matters. The bill, for example, specifically prohibits the government from negotiating discounts or lower drug prices, and bars the importation of cheaper drugs from abroad.
And then there's the "demonstration" project, to begin in 2010, in which Medicare will be forced in several cities to compete against private, profit-making health plans. It will be a rigged competition in that, among other things, the private plans will be heavily subsidized by Medicare money and will be able to cherry-pick the healthiest patients.
As one Capitol Hill staffer told me last week: "This is more than the camel's nose under the tent. This is like the head, the hump and everything else."
Harry Truman would be beside himself.

HEADLINE: California's New Governor Is Fighting a Familiar Battle 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
Arnold Schwarzenegger ran for governor promising to end business as usual in Sacramento.
 But this weekend's collapse of negotiations over Mr. Schwarzenegger's budget-balancing strategy, and the partisan finger-pointing that quickly followed, certainly resembled the politics as usual that California voters appeared to reject when they recalled the governor, Gray Davis, in October and replaced him with Mr. Schwarzenegger. 
 California lawmakers late Friday night rejected a plan by Mr. Schwarzenegger to float a $15 billion bond issue to bail the state out of debt, coupled with a constitutional amendment limiting future spending by a fixed formula. Friday was the deadline for the Legislature to act to place both measures on the March ballot. 
In the aftermath of Friday's defeat, Mr. Schwarzenegger's aides vowed to bypass the Legislature and put the measures on the ballot next November by gathering signatures from the public. The governor is also preparing to isolate the Legislature further by putting several other initiatives before the voters, including changes to the state's workers' compensation system, a plan to open more government records, a campaign finance measure and a proposal to expand legalized gambling.
"He's now preparing to go to the ballot, just as he said he would during the campaign," said Rob Stutzman, Mr. Schwarzenegger's communications director. "Taking a bad deal is not what the voters sent him here to do."
Politicians and political analysts here, depending on their partisan stripes, interpreted the latest budget debacle as a major setback for the new governor or as a black eye for the Democrats who control both houses of the Legislature by large margins.
But despite the rhetoric from both sides, each may have achieved precisely what it wanted from the impasse, some lawmakers said.
Mr. Schwarzenegger can now mount his bully pulpit and accuse the Democrats of being "spending addicts," as he did Friday night. He can spend much of next year campaigning for his ballot proposals and demonizing a do-nothing Legislature.
Democrats can say they stopped a Republican power grab and protected programs serving children and the poor from the new governor's indiscriminate budget ax.
And the ideological divide that separates the parties in Sacramento and feeds the political paralysis here may just grow deeper.
"Everyone had more incentive for there not to be a deal than for there to be a deal," Assemblyman Joseph Canciamilla, a moderate Democrat from Northern California who has tried for months to create a bipartisan budget solution, said in a telephone interview on Sunday.
"Everyone got the sound bite they were looking for, and in the meantime we still have a huge financial problem in this state that has yet to be addressed," he said.
Mr. Canciamilla and others from both parties said Mr. Schwarzenegger's far-reaching proposals, coming just two weeks after he was sworn in, might have been doomed from the start. The plan to issue as much as $15 billion in long-term debt to underwrite a short-term deficit came under criticism from conservative Republicans as well as Democrats.
The governor's plan to rewrite the state Constitution to cap future spending was even more controversial. It would have limited growth in spending to a formula based on inflation and population growth, while giving the governor sweeping powers to cut spending in a fiscal crisis without legislative approval.
Mr. Schwarzenegger demanded that the two be linked, saying he was unwilling to increase the state's indebtedness without assurance that future spending would be contained.
In the end, bipartisan majorities rejected both proposals and lawmakers went home for the rest of the year, unless Mr. Schwarzenegger calls them back into special session -- and the Democratic leaders agree to come.
Phil Angelides, the elected state treasurer, spent the week traveling around California speaking against the governor's proposals. Mr. Angelides, a Democrat, said that financing current deficits with long-term debt was a recipe for fiscal disaster. No state has ever borrowed so much money to pay current bills, he said.
"Fifteen billion dollars is not chicken feed," said Mr. Angelides, who is expected to run for governor in 2006. "It is not a small move. It's a dramatic departure from the way this state has paid its bills before."
Mr. Angelides also said that Mr. Schwarzenegger's spending-limit plan would hobble the state's ability to respond to future crises.
"The idea of adopting a plan in three weeks that will constrain us for the next 30 years is the worst kind of public policy," he said. "Borrowing and imposing a cap don't move us one inch closer to a balanced budget. It's an illusion of budget balancing. It's Hollywood optics."
Mr. Stutzman, the governor's spokesman, said the mood among the governor and his aides this weekend was more frustration than anger. He said Mr. Schwarzenegger had addressed Assembly Republicans on Friday night as his proposals were collapsing under Democratic objections.
"They're like addicts," the governor said, according to Mr. Stutzman. "They mean well. They want to stop, but they can't. They need a people's intervention."

HEADLINE: A REGION INFLAMED: INSURGENCY; 
General Sees More Attacks as Elections Near

BYLINE:  By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
The commander of American military forces in Iraq said Sunday that he expected guerrilla attacks and related violence to increase in the coming months, as Iraq moves toward national elections next summer.
 The commander, Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, added that insurgent forces were bent on disrupting Iraq's transition to democracy and "will have to conduct some sort of operations against the political and economic sector." 
 "We expect to see an increase in violence as we move toward the transfer of sovereignty in June and July," he added. 
General Sanchez noted that the number of attacks against occupation forces had decreased in the last two weeks, as the military had stepped up its offensive operations. But his remarks at a news conference about expected violence in the next six months show that the military does not expect any sort of decisive defeat of insurgent forces in the foreseeable future.
He added that even if American forces captured or killed Saddam Hussein, a goal that remains a top priority, that would not extinguish the resolve of the guerrilla fighters, as some officials have predicted.
"The killing or capturing of Saddam Hussein will have an impact on the violence," he said, "but it will not end it."
The general emphasized the military's resolve to attack the insurgents at every opportunity, using whatever weapons seem appropriate, including 500-pound bombs and other heavy munitions. But the larger message from his remarks seems to be that United States and allied forces are facing a long, hard slog with no apparent end in sight.
In Mosul on Sunday, one American soldier was killed and another was wounded when a roadside bomb blew up under an Army Humvee, the military said. That death brings to 192 the number of American soldiers killed in combat since President Bush declared major combat over on May 1.
Another bomb hidden in garbage beside the road in Iskandariya killed a child on Saturday evening, the military reported Sunday. The child's identity was not made public.
Iraqi journalists at the news conference peppered the general with questions about accusations of mistreatment of Iraqi civilians during recent offensive operations. But he remained unruffled and undeterred.
Asked if he was worried that the military's offensive posture was alienating the population, turning them against the American occupiers, General Sanchez said he and his commanders "talk about this" before launching operations. He added that the military tried to make "a very clear effort on our part to be sure we are not alienating people."
The strategy for that, he said, was "to go back and help the people" after each attack. He added that "when damage is done, we come back and assist the people and correct the problem" by resettling displaced people or restoring damaged buildings, for example.
Still, he insisted: "The answer is clear. The only way you win in combat is to stay on the offensive."
The larger strategy for reducing the attacks against Americans is to train thousands of Iraqi police, security and military forces over the next year to take their place. General Sanchez said the military had decided to increase the size of the Iraqi Civil Defense Corps, a paramilitary force that helps fight the insurgency, to 40,000 in the coming year from its current strength of 13,000.
But he insisted that one plan, trumpeted by several Iraqi officials last week, would never be put in place. Several members of the Iraqi Governing Council reported then that they had reached agreement with the American military to incorporate fighters from each of seven private militias that belong to seven different political parties. These fighters, 700 to 1,000 in all, would be formed into a new battalion, the Iraqis said.
General Sanchez said those reports were false.
"Our position has been consistent," he said. "We will allow Iraqis to join our security forces at any time," he said, but "they will be coming in as individuals," not militiamen, "under our command and control."
"There is no place for militias," he added. The occupation authorities banned private militias months ago and vowed to disband them. But aside from one small militia in Karbala that the Army disbanded by force after it attacked an American military police unit in October, the private militias have been left largely untouched.

HEADLINE: A Centrist, Lieberman Fights For Votes in an Extremist Era 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
It is a quiet Sunday morning in early fall on Franklin Street in Concord, N.H., and Joe Lieberman is being his indefatigably genial self, campaigning door to door -- listening intently to voters, nodding thoughtfully while a herd of flowerbed-trampling reporters and factotums snorts and stamps on his tail.
 Out beyond the curb, a handmade sign bobs above the heads of the onlookers. It is a sheet of white poster board studded with images of bloodied children. The couple carrying it have abandoned their morning coffee to let Mr. Lieberman know how they feel about his enthusiastic support for the war in Iraq. 
 Undaunted, he wades across the sidewalk to meet them. They confront him, he listens; he starts to respond, they remonstrate some more. Two doors up, another Iraq question awaits him, this time from a woman with her son in tow. Again, Mr. Lieberman takes time to make his case. 
He supported the war, he tells her undefensively; he believes it was the right thing to do. The world is safer, he says, with Saddam Hussein removed from power. But he is stunned by the Bush administration's mishandling of the aftermath, he says. It should have reached out immediately for international help.
He thanks the woman for her question; he invites her to a town hall meeting that night; he suggests she visit his campaign Web site. Starting up the sidewalk with his wife, Hadassah, he turns back to the questioner one more time, as though loath to give up on the possibility of winning her over.
"Probably you and I agree on most things," he suggests.
The woman nods. But her expression is opaque.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has built his career doing what he did that morning: wading across ideological divides, hunting for common ground and doing it with a mix of civility and conviction that at its best has won over Democrats, Republicans and independents alike.
Yet Mr. Lieberman is running for the presidency at a time when many Democrats appear to have lost the appetite for conciliation. They are angry, and not least about the Republican administration's war, which Mr. Lieberman, a Democrat, went out of his way to support.
What becomes of a candidate who has built his record on bipartisanship at a moment when many in his own party want nothing to do with the other side? And what becomes of a mild-mannered centrist in a crowded field when the surest route to the limelight is to blurt out something extreme?
As Mr. Lieberman sees it, anger does not win general elections. "Voters want somebody who's strong, that they can trust to make things better," he says. And they want someone who can beat President Bush, which he says he is well positioned to do in part because of his record on national security and values.
But others wonder: Have his assets become liabilities?
"The Democrats are in no mood to make peace with the Republicans," said William E. Curry Jr., an aide to President Bill Clinton and a longtime friend of Mr. Lieberman. "And the public is in no mood to make peace with Washington.
"It's a hard time for his strengths," Mr. Curry said. "His strengths may not look like strengths in that environment. But that doesn't mean they wouldn't be every bit as valuable in governing."

Shaped by the 60's
Mr. Lieberman is not easy to pigeonhole. He is progressive on social issues, moderate on fiscal issues, conservative on national security. Pegged a moderate, he prefers "independent minded." 
Abortion rights groups and environmental groups rate him highly. He was active in the civil rights movement and an early opponent of discrimination against gays. In 2002, National Journal rated him one of the most "socially liberal" senators.
But he is also pro-business, pro-growth, pro-trade and pro-defense -- all hallmarks of the Democratic Leadership Council, the centrist group that nurtured the presidential ambitions of Bill Clinton, Al Gore and now Mr. Lieberman. He has supported limited experiments with school vouchers. He has voted for tax cuts on capital gains and the V-chip, which lets parents block television programs. He has been known to ally himself with the likes of William J. Bennett and Orrin G. Hatch.
He parts company with fellow Democrats, most notably on national security. He was the lead Democratic co-sponsor of the Senate resolution that authorized the 1991 Persian Gulf war, and last year he became one of the most outspoken Congressional Democrats favoring invading Iraq.
"He's a kind of rara avis," said Colin McEnroe, a writer and the host of a drive-time talk radio show on WTIC-AM in Connecticut who has known Mr. Lieberman since the 1970's. "What you have in Joe Lieberman is a guy who was shaped by the 60's, who marched with Martin Luther King, whose beliefs were forged in the crucible of being at Yale in a time of social change.
"You've got all that, but that's fused with -- he's an Orthodox Jew. And there are things that go along with that that are perhaps more conservative in nature. You can't look at Lieberman the way you would look at some other Democrat of a comparable age and lineage. He's a different guy. He believes in the dream of Martin Luther King, but he also believes in the Old Testament."
In his personal style, too, Mr. Lieberman is an unexpected mix.
He uses the phrase "the American dream" without the quotation marks. He telephones his 89-year-old mother, Marcia, every day. He says "God bless you" often, as in, "You kids are what it's all about. God bless you." Even after being loudly heckled, he has been known to address an audience, "Dear friends."
He is often accused of sanctimoniousness. And during the 2000 presidential campaign, when as Mr. Gore's running mate he suggested, "There must be a place for faith in America's public life," he was taken to task by the Anti-Defamation League, which accused him of "almost hawking" his faith.
But Mr. Lieberman is also funny, in a mildly self-mocking sort of way. A former colleague in the Connecticut State Senate fondly recalled his "wry detachment." Asked recently at a campaign event how he was holding up on the trail, he answered, without missing a beat, that he was planning to donate his body to science for a study of the long-term effects of Clif Bars.
The roots of Mr. Lieberman's moderation, personally and politically, can be traced as far back as his early childhood in Stamford, Conn., which he spent with his family in the home of his maternal grandmother, an Austrian immigrant and widowed mother of five who, he has written, never took her freedom and opportunity here for granted "and she made sure I didn't either."
Mr. Lieberman's political skills are said to have come from his gregarious mother, still a campaign trail presence, ensconced in a wheelchair, a large black pocketbook across her lap. During his 1994 shoo-in Senate race, Mr. Lieberman's staff used to joke that the only way he would lose would be if Marcia Lieberman ran against him.
He was a multiple-term class president and a prom king who spent much of his weekends at temple and in religious study. He grew up steeped in the concept of tikkun olam, the obligation to improve the world, and in the belief that to serve God, one must serve one's fellow humans.
He was a reader of history. The stories that impressed him most were the stories of leaders like Winston Churchill, who, as he put it recently, "saw the evil of fascism and Nazism and rallied the world to stop it," and Harry S. Truman, "who saw the outbreak of Communism for what it was and was instrumental in creating NATO and keeping America strong to push back Communism."
Asked about his own willingness to resort to military solutions to aggression in the world, Mr. Lieberman said, "Part of this may come from my religious upbringing and sort of world view that, you know, there is evil in the world and if good people don't stand up to try to stop it, it will spread and a lot of people will be hurt."
The first in his family to go to college, Mr. Lieberman entered Yale in the fall of 1960. He joined a class on a cusp between the passivity of the 1950's and the activism that followed. If he was shaped by the decade, it was by the early part -- the civil rights movement -- more than by the Vietnam War, which he supported until about 1967.
He was elected chairman of The Yale Daily News. He joined the March on Washington in 1963. And at the urging of William Sloane Coffin, then the Yale chaplain, he went to Mississippi later that year to help register black voters for a mock election, a precursor to the 1964 Freedom Summer.
He immersed himself in politics. He wrote his senior thesis, which became his first book, on John M. Bailey of Connecticut, then the Democratic National Committee chairman and one of the most effective political bosses in the country. And he worked as an intern for Abraham Ribicoff, the United States senator from Connecticut and a mentor, from whom he learned the meaning of the phrase "the integrity of compromise."
David Wyles, a college roommate, says he and Mr. Lieberman came to Yale from comparable class backgrounds. But Mr. Wyles, a scholarship student, took campus jobs. "Busing dishes for these rich preppies and having them treat me like a servant," Mr. Wyles says, he became a radical. Mr. Lieberman took another route.
"He saw going into politics as a viable alternative," Mr. Wyles said. "You know what? It's not in his nature to be a radical. He's a balanced person. He listens to people. He rarely goes too far in the pendulum because he's always thinking about what other people think. Not that he doesn't have his own moral compass. But he reaches out to other people.
"I think he has a definite sympathy for the underclass, for immigrants, for blacks, for Latinos. But it's not like he doesn't relate to insurance executives either. That's part of buying into the American dream: 'We can all become middle class.' Of course, it's not true, but he believes it."

Taking on an Incumbent
Connecticut politics in the 1970's was not a bad place for Mr. Lieberman's moderate inclinations. Neither party had a lock on the governorship or the Legislature; both sides courted independents. The tone was collegial. Three years out of Yale Law School, Mr. Lieberman was elected to the State Senate from New Haven.
He rose quickly to the position of Senate majority leader. He worked closely with Ella T. Grasso, then the governor, whom he admired as a "New Democrat before anyone coined the term" -- fiscally responsible and a believer in what he calls "that wonderful Paul Tsongas line that you can't be pro-jobs and antibusiness."
After an unsuccessful campaign for a United States House seat in 1980, he was elected Connecticut's attorney general in 1982. He is widely credited with having reinvented that office, turning it from a backwater into an activist operation. Dogging polluters and consumer frauds, he was in the news constantly. He became one of the most popular politicians inthe state.
"A lot of progressives in the party began in those days to see him as a progressive, maybe mistakenly so," said Toby Moffett, a former Democratic representative from Connecticut, who said the issues the office handled lent themselves to that interpretation. "I don't think he was faking anything, I think that's where he was. But I think it gave the impression that he was a liberal. And maybe he never was."
In 1988, Mr. Lieberman took on Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the renegade Republican United States senator who had become famous during Watergate by denouncing President Richard M. Nixon. Mr. Lieberman entered the race as a long shot. But with a strategy interpreted by some as brilliant and others as baldly opportunistic, he closed the gap with just three weeks to go and won.
He ran to the left and to the right of Mr. Weicker. He attacked his record on environmental and consumer protection while accusing him of being weak on foreign policy and crime. He let fly a series of television advertisements caricaturing Mr. Weicker as a hibernating bear who woke only to collect honoraria. Mr. Lieberman's victory sharpened his image, for better and worse.
"Weicker was a gigantic figure," Mr. McEnroe said. "What Lieberman did was to create a political opportunity that didn't exist. It showed that underneath this gentle, smiling, soft-spoken, Ivy League persona -- this Jewish Dalai Lama thing he does -- he could, if he had to, get out the chain saw. Nobody could look at that campaign and say, 'This guy can't play hardball.' "
The memory still angers Weicker supporters.
Thomas J. D'Amore Jr., a political consultant and lobbyist who worked on the Weicker campaign, said: "Lieberman was prepared to change his positions and views on almost anything, including campaigning. He started out his political career as a genuine liberal. That all changed. I don't know if that's a question of someone maturing or being politically ambitious.
"Part of what's deceptive about Joe is he is a very soft-spoken and pleasant individual. He's got that quality about him that Dick Cheney does. They speak in very soft, reassuring tones and therefore don't sound threatening. But you need to listen very carefully to what they say."
Shortly before the 1988 election, Peter G. Kelly, a former national finance chairman for the Democratic Party, introduced Mr. Lieberman to Al From, the founder of the Democratic Leadership Council, the Washington group that admirers now credit with having helped modernize the Democratic Party and detractors blame for moving it to the right.
What the council had done, Mr. Kelly said recently, was put together a "substantive credo" for moderates -- on which Bill Clinton later ran for president and governed. Mr. Lieberman became involved with the council early in his first term in the Senate. By 1995 he was chairman. It became for him both a source of ideas and a link to a network of political contacts.
He has worked with its research group, the Progressive Policy Institute, on ideas for everything from economic policy and defense modernization to welfare and education reform. Through the council, he says, he formed important Senate friendships with Sam Nunn of Georgia, John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Charles S. Robb of Virginia. Mr. From is a close adviser and friend.
"It was a huge turning point," Mr. Kelly said of Mr. Lieberman's coming together with the council. "One of the great lessons for the Democrats is that if you stand in the center of the spectrum, it's very hard to be beaten. Because somebody else can't get enough on the left or right to take you down. Joe has very strongly occupied the center."

Criticism From Two Sides
In 2000, Mr. Lieberman's centrism helped land him the vice presidential nomination. But he did not emerge from that experience unscathed. Liberal Democrats accused him of not being sufficiently Democratic, while Republicans savaged him as being too Democratic and revamping his positions to suit his running mate. 
He was criticized, after a Los Angeles fund-raiser, as having seemed to soft-pedal earlier criticisms of the entertainment industry's excesses. Republicans accused him of abandoning school vouchers and Social Security privatization -- though he says he had already written off privatization as a bad idea and simply stopped talking about vouchers during the campaign because Mr. Gore opposed them.
Once Mr. Bush was elected, Mr. Lieberman voted against his 2001 and 2003 tax cuts. He co-sponsored an amendment to stop the administration from opening the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge to drilling. He voted against confirming John Ashcroft as attorney general and Gale A. Norton as interior secretary. But on Iraq, he praised the president's case as "eloquent, powerful and convincing."
"Unfortunately for Joe," said Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's delegate to Congress and a critic of Iraq policy, "the war has become the Achilles' heel for the president and therefore it will be the Achilles' heel for anybody who embraced the president's view. And Joe is so principled that he reiterates his views on the war and gets booed for it."
The Lieberman campaign has lately been struggling for traction. Last month, it opted to bypass Iowa's presidential caucuses. Mr. Lieberman is now pinning his hopes on the second round of primary states like Oklahoma and Arizona. Even in Connecticut, Howard Dean has made inroads.
"What Howard Dean has tapped into is a frustration among Democrats like myself with the willingness of our party to go along with the Republican agenda," said J. Brendan Sharkey, a state representative from Hamden, Conn., who is supporting Mr. Dean. Of Mr. Lieberman, he said, "I think he's perceived generally as a lite version of the Bush agenda."
Mr. Lieberman's supporters counter that party mathematics are in his favor: They say only one-third of Democrats call themselves liberal while many more call themselves moderate to conservative.
"It remains to be seen whether moderates will participate other than moderately," Mr. Kelly said.
It is late Sunday night in Hartford and Mr. Lieberman is sitting in the back seat of his car with a reporter and his campaign press secretary, Jano Cabrera, while the engine hums and the driver idles outside his hotel.
So, what have you ever done to excess? Mr. Lieberman is asked.
"Um, you know, love my children," he answers teasingly. "Pray to God."
He chuckles.
"I'm sorry, I can't . . . To excess? What do you mean?"
The question is rephrased.
"Oh, when I was a kid, I drank too much," he offers.
Nothing in the last 40 years?
Mr. Cabrera leans forward: "I'm just as curious as she is, sir."
A pause.
"You want to hear about the wild. . . ." Mr. Lieberman begins. "Naah. I can't tell you. Excess? I can't think of anything. Or anything I want to say. Let's leave a little mystery here."

Challenging Bush
This is the fifth article of a series examining the lives and careers of the candidates seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. In addition, an audio slide show is online at nytimes.com/campaigns.
