HEADLINE: U.S. Suits Multiply, But Fewer Ever Get To Trial, Study Says 

BYLINE:  By ADAM LIPTAK

 BODY:
On television and in the popular imagination, lawsuits and prosecutions end in trials, in open court before a jury. In reality, according to a new study, trials have become quite uncommon. 
 In 1962, the study says, 11.5 percent of all civil cases in federal court went to trial. By last year, that number had dropped to 1.8 percent. And even though there are five times as many lawsuits today, the raw number of civil trials has dropped, too. They peaked in 1985 at 12,529. Last year, 4,569 civil cases were tried in federal court. 
 "What's documented here," William G. Young, the chief judge of the Federal District Court in Boston, said in a telephone interview, "is nothing less than the passing of the common law adversarial system that is uniquely American."
The percentage of federal criminal prosecutions resolved by trials also declined, to less than 5 percent last year from 15 percent in 1962. The number of prosecutions more than doubled in the last four decades, but the number of criminal trials fell, to 3,574 last year from 5,097 in 1962.
The study, based on data compiled by the federal court system, was prepared by Marc Galanter, who teaches law at the University of Wisconsin and the London School of Economics, for the American Bar Association. 
"This is a cultural shift of enormous significance," said Arthur Miller, a law professor at Harvard.
Opinions vary on whether the shift is a positive one. Negotiated settlements may satisfy both sides in a way a win-or-lose trial cannot, and pretrial dismissals of cases by judges may avoid needless trials of frivolous claims. Both of these alternatives to trial are less cumbersome, less expensive and more efficient. 
On the other hand, some studies suggest that individuals suing companies fare considerably better before juries than they do in settlements and before judges, meaning that a decline in the number of trials may hurt plaintiffs with valid claims.
Judges, scholars and lawyers gathered over the weekend in San Francisco for a bar association symposium to discuss the study. Among the possible explanations for what the meeting's organizers call "the vanishing trial" is a growing antagonism to trials by lawyers and judges, who consider them costly and risky. They prefer negotiated settlements and pretrial determinations by judges based only on paper submissions.
"There is a striking philosophical, ideologically driven view that is hostile to trials," said Judge Patrick E. Higginbotham of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans. He attributed the view to those who prefer mediation to adjudication.
Others view the trend as progress.
"If a trial occurs," said Samuel R. Gross, a law professor at the University of Michigan, "it usually means a whole lot of efforts by a whole lot of people have failed."
Paul Butler, a law professor at George Washington University, disagreed. He said the loss of this form of dispute resolution was a devastating one. "Nobody does trials like Americans," Professor Butler said. "We made it an art form. It's almost as fundamental a part of our culture as jazz or rock 'n' roll."
Data from the state courts, which handle most lawsuits, are less complete and harder to interpret. Legal experts at the National Center for State Courts have studied the available data and say the patterns in them, particularly as they concern jury trials as opposed to those before only judges, are broadly consistent with those in the federal courts.
Judge Higginbotham recalled his life as a federal trial judge in Texas a quarter-century ago. "When I went on the bench," he said, "we tried cases. I sometimes had three juries deliberating."
In 1962, the average federal judge conducted 39 trials a year, including both civil and criminal cases. These days, that number has fallen to 13. Judges spend the rest of their time doing such things as supervising the exchange of information between parties, deciding pretrial motions and urging or approving settlements and plea bargains.
The dearth of trials has resulted in a sort of vicious circle. Many lawyers who call themselves litigators have little trial experience, which may in turn make them wary of taking cases to trial.
"We're almost moving into a barrister model," said Patricia Lee Refo, an Arizona lawyer and official of the American Bar Association, referring to the separate caste of lawyers who try cases in Britain.
On the criminal side, there is almost no dispute that the falling number of trials in the federal courts is because of the revisions in sentencing laws. Defendants who insist on a trial can face much longer sentences than those who accept a plea bargain.
The civil trend is harder to explain, and legal experts have many theories.
Some point to the rise of arbitrations and other less formal means of resolving disputes. Though the number of cases filed in court has continued to increase, it may be that some sorts of cases have gone to other forums. Injury and contract cases, which represented 74 percent of all federal civil trials in 1962, accounted for 38 percent last year, according to Professor Galanter. Those categories of cases, he said, have largely been replaced by employment discrimination and other civil rights cases, which now represent a third of all federal civil trials.
The sheer complexity and cost of litigation, others say, make settlements more attractive. The cost of a trial can exceed the cost of a settlement, giving defendants an incentive to settle. Plaintiffs and their lawyers, on the other hand, often prefer the certainty of a settlement to the possibility of recovering nothing at trial. 
"The striking problem," Professor Gross said, "is that we have generated a procedure that is way too expensive if actually employed."
But Gillian Hadfield, a law professor at the University of Southern California, said settlements might actually be in decline. 
"We need to follow up on this initial study to confirm these numbers," Professor Hadfield said, "but at this point it looks as though the percentage of cases terminated in settlement has fallen by between 10 and 15 percentage points, from approximately 50 percent in 1970 to between 35 and 40 percent during the 1980's and 1990's."
By contrast, she continued, "nontrial adjudications" -- written decisions by judges typically based only on papers submitted by the parties -- have risen to 50 percent from 32 percent since 1970.
Professor Miller said such judicial decisions can be troubling.
"We speak glowingly of letting people have their day in court," he said. "Now they have their day on papers."

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried

 BODY:
Getting On With Life After Nearly Losing It
She still loves New York, Nicole Barrett says, though it would be understandable if her feelings about the city were less positive.
 In November 1999, Ms. Barrett, who was then 27 and had moved to the city from Texas a year earlier, was nearly killed when a man slammed a brick into the back of her head on a sunny afternoon at a busy Manhattan intersection. 
 The act of random brutality, at 42nd Street and Madison Avenue, drew national news coverage and served as a sharp reminder that the city's falling crime rate hardly meant immunity from violence. A panhandler with a long criminal history that included drug-peddling convictions was found guilty of first-degree assault and is serving 25 years in prison.
When Ms. Barrett, who had been working temporary office jobs and thinking of a career in interior design, was released from the hospital after a month, her doctors -- who had twice operated to relieve pressure on her brain -- said she might have suffered permanent brain damage. She was still having severe headaches and problems speaking and making decisions at the time. She went to Athens, Tex., to live with her parents while continuing to recuperate and undergo therapy.
These days, Ms. Barrett says, she occasionally gets dizzy spells and contends with a partial loss of hearing in one ear. Sometimes "I can't explain things" and "tend to forget things," she said recently from Dallas, where she now lives. She is studying interior design at the Art Institute of Dallas. But the bigger impact, she said, has been on her personality.
"I think I'm a lot more subdued than I used to be," she said, adding that she also lacks her old self-confidence. 
"There are things I don't do that I think about and that I always wanted to do," she said. She "loved to fly" planes and took lessons before the assault, she said, but now hesitates to resume the lessons because of a heavy awareness that "anything can happen in a split second."
Ms. Barrett said she had tried living in New York again in 2000, months after the attack, but it "didn't work out" because it was too soon, and she returned to Texas after three months. But she has since visited the city, she said, and "it is not out of the question" that she might move back.
Ms. Barrett could not identify her attacker. The man convicted, Paris Drake, insisted that he was innocent and the victim of mistaken identification by two witnesses. His lawyer, Richard Greenberg, said he was working on an appeal.
Ms. Barrett said she had no hatred for the person who so shattered her life. "I just wonder what was going on in his mind then," she said, "and what is today."

No Toilet Surcharge On His Cellphone Bill
Extricated again.
On Oct. 29, a Bronx man, Edwin Gallart, 41, got into a most unwelcome situation while riding a Metro-North Railroad train out of Grand Central Terminal: his arm became trapped from hand to elbow in a toilet when he reached into it to retrieve his cellphone, which had fallen in.
The train was halted at the Fordham station in the Bronx while firefighters freed his arm by using power tools to tear the stainless steel bowl from the lavatory and slice it apart.
Other trains had to be rerouted, bypassing five Bronx stations and inconveniencing passengers.
Mr. Gallart's cellphone was not found, but his unhappy tale found its way into the news. Then, adding to his woes, Metro-North said it was considering whether to bill him for the nearly $3,000 cost of obtaining and installing a new bowl. 
Last week, though, a spokesman for Metro-North said it would not seek payment. "The expense of trying to recover, we believe, would be economically unfeasible," the spokesman, Dan Brucker, said.
Mr. Gallart could not be reached for comment. Whether he has a new cellphone could not be determined, but his home phone number is unlisted.

HEADLINE: Antique Sales Slow and Shops Are Closing 

BYLINE:  By JAMES LOMUSCIO

 BODY:
EDWARD CARNEY stepped into Greenwillow Antiques in Cannondale not to buy, but in the hope of selling advertising space in a TransWestern phone directory. Instead, he heard a familiar refrain from antiques dealers. Business is down and they won't be buying much advertising until things improve.
 "What I need first are a few more rings on the register. I've been hanging on like this," said Lynn Brinker, the owner of the shop, holding her arms up and digging her nails into an imaginary sill. 
 She said customers have been spending less because in uncertain times they stop buying things that are not necessities, such as antiques. She volunteered her books that showed how monthly sales have tumbled consistently to about one-fifth of what they were in 1999. Even Mr. Carney's soft sell could not cinch a deal for a display ad. 
"What I'm selling is only $41 a month for a one-and-a-half-inch column ad," he said understandingly. "But that's $41 she could put toward her rent."
Though she is struggling, Ms. Brinker can count herself better off than other antiques dealers, especially in Fairfield County where rising rents coupled with a sluggish economy and Internet competition have shuttered a number of shops. At least she is still opened and traffic has picked up a bit during the holiday season. Other dealers have gone to smaller quarters, moved out of the area or consolidated with other sellers.
Among the antiques stores that have closed this past year are Maury Rose in Branchville, the Forgotten Garden in Wilton, Hunter's Consignments in Ridgefield and Prince of Wales in Westport.
Even Wayside Antiques, a destination for more than 40 years at the intersection of Routes 33 and 7 in Wilton, and owned for the past two years by Peter Curran, the appraiser on the PBS series, "Antiques Roadshow," shut its doors this past May.
"I personally think it's pretty bleak, and I've heard horror stories from other dealers who have gone months without sales," Mr. Curran said.
He said the situation in Fairfield County has been exacerbated by rising real estate values that have caused commercial rents to soar. Mr. Curran said with declining sales he could not afford Wayside's $9,000 a month rent.
"At this point I've returned a lot of the stuff I had on consignment, and I'm basically phasing it out," said Mr. Curran, who has since moved his stock to a small garage behind a Wilton hardware store.
Mr. Curran, who said he literally grew up in his mother's antiques shop in New York, said that while the recessionary mid-1970's and late 1980's were flat periods, "this is the worst." One of the great ironies, he added, is that extremely high-end items, such as six-figure paintings and furnishings are doing well, while "the low end is taking a hit."
George Subkoff, a Westport antiques dealer, said that while business had slowed, "the really best things are selling." Mr. Subkoff, whose family has been dealing in antiques since 1908, sells mostly 18th-century furniture and furnishings with prices ranging from $800 to $200,000. Despite knowing that the nearby Jordan-Delhaise Antiques is vacating in the fall to move to Woodbury, Mr. Subkoff remained optimistic.
"It's cyclical," he said. "And there's so much money around here, and people are putting it into their homes, and eventually they'll want to furnish it with the appropriate trappings."
What about the gloomy forecast from other struggling antiques dealers?
"Like everything else, when everybody cries the most, that's when things start to turn around," Mr. Subkoff said.
Noel Edwards, who owns Consignart in Bethel, said he would like to believe that's the case. But all he has to do is look at the number of businesses for sale in an antiques newspaper to convince him that the industry is hurting. That and the fact "98 percent of the people who come in don't buy, and attendance of those is down, too."
"If you have to pay the rent and depend upon this business to survive, you're not going to make it," he said. "A lot of the people who are surviving are doing so because they have some money behind them. Someone is holding them up somehow."
The antiques business, like many others, began to sour after the Sept. 11 attacks and worsened with the war in Iraq, dealers said. 
"It's affected the psychology of people when it comes to buying, and the first things they stop buying are the things they don't really need, which are antiques," Mr. Edwards said. "And if you want my real feelings, I personally think things are going to get a lot worse in this business because of people's fear."
Other dealers, while admitting times are tough, were less grim and saw the downturn as an opportunity to rework their business strategies. Richard Miles, who had owned Cromlix Antiques and Consignments on Main Street in Ridgefield for 10 years, had considered going out of business due to rising rents and falling sales until Carla Devens, who owns C. Devens Consignments a few doors down, offered him an alternative. 
"I said you can come and work out of my store because I have a large back room," Ms. Devens recalled. "And it worked out well for me, too, because it gives me freedom. He helps me move furniture, I'm not alone, and now I can take two days off a week."
Cynthia Reiss, who owns Cynthia's Attic Treasures in the Branchville section of Ridgefield, said that about a year ago she began selling items on eBay.
"I had been fighting it, because I didn't want to spend my time in front of a computer," Ms. Reiss said. "But to survive in this industry in this environment you have to have a lot of different outlets."
She also said dealers have to offer items across a wide price spectrum.
"You'll have people come in, and they'll be looking at a $10 cup and saucer, and they might wind up buying a $100 painting," she said. "But they won't just stop in on their way somewhere and buy a $2,000 piece of furniture."
Across Route 7 at King and I Antiques, Shirley Stendahl-McLeod, said she has had to diversify by running estate sales, auctioning some of her more expensive pieces and doing appraisals. Ms. Stendahl-McLeod also relinquished half of her retail space, to cut her $60,000 a year rent in half. 
"Now we have about $1,500 square feet, and we consolidated it all, it fits and it looks great," she said.
In September, Jordan-Delhaise Antiques on Post Road East in Westport left after Michel Delhaise and George Jordan, the owners, were unable to negotiate a new lease. They moved their business, which specializes in American and European fine art and furniture, to a cooperative with three other dealers at the Main Street Antiques Center in Woodbury. 
"It's easier for us as far as time management is concerned because we're only working two days a week instead of six, and we're saving money," Mr. Delhaise said. "The rents are much more reasonable here for independent businesses. I'm very optimistic."
The Main Street Antiques Center is owned by Peggy Heminway, president of the Woodbury Antiques Dealers Association, which has 45 members. This fall one of their strategies to shake the industry's doldrums was an advertising campaign touting Woodbury as an autumn destination. She said this past year had been unpredictable.
"You could have a great month, but then it might be dead for the next month and a half," she said.
But since the fall, she said business has gotten better.
"The holiday season has picked up and either the economy as a whole is boosting us or the ad campaign has had a positive impact," she said. "We're looking forward to the New Year." 
"This past year, things were unpredictable," Ms. Heminway said. "You could have a great month, but then it might be dead for the next month and a half. But in the past three months we've seen a more consistent flow." 
Edie Van Breems, co-owner of Eleish-Van Breems in Woodbury, viewed the association's efforts optimistically, especially with the decorator business picking up.
"We sell 18th-and 19th-century Swedish antiques, and being highly specialized can be either a good thing or a bad thing, because your average buyer wasn't coming in and doing impulse buying," she said.
"It made us really look at the bottom line," Ms. Van Breems added, "We began to sell down our inventory and to take less buying trips, even to look at the prices of hotels we'd stay at when buying. These were all things we wouldn't have though of doing when times were good, things like our magazine subscriptions, phone service, even our oil company." 
In Ridgefield, Ms. Devens said the antiques business will survive because there are always people who love antiques.
"It's the workmanship, the beauty of something handmade, something made with love by one person," she said. "Things made by machine do not have the same vibrations."
And about claims that antiques are not necessary items, Mr. Subkoff in Westport countered, "They feed the soul."

HEADLINE: Mr. Rowland's Neighborhood: Quiet and Not Too Flashy 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
IT was shortly before noon on a recent December day at the Morris Deli and the line was already snaking past the candy jars and down the cereal aisle. A man wearing insulated coveralls was eating shepherd's pie off a paper plate. Others were ordering overstuffed sandwiches to eat in their pick-up trucks. Homemade cookies sat under a glass dome. 
 This is the shop, in a dirt parking lot behind Popeye's Ice Cream and across from Morris Town Hall, where Gov. John G. Rowland buys worms. 
 "Yep," said the owner of the deli, Lisa Dreher, clearly proud, "this is where he buys his bait."
It's a 10-minute drive from here to 37 Van Winkle Road, where the governor has a summer cottage in Litchfield on Bantam Lake. A federal investigation into the awarding of state contracts has put the cottage in the news and three people who worked on the house have been subpoenaed to testify about how they may have been promised state work in exchange for low-priced renovations. But for many who live or summer here, Mr. Rowland is, above all, a neighbor. The fact that he appears to cherish his privacy seems to strike a chord with many people.
"You see him out fishing a lot and smoking a cigar, mostly because his wife doesn't let him smoke at home or he's out on his boat with the kids," said George Sigiel, a real estate agent.
Although Bantam Lake has families who have summered here for a century --the Bayleys are the first name that comes to the mind of Morris Town Clerk Ann E. Carr -- it isn't the kind of place where new people are shut out. Witness the Rowlands, who bought their 1,200 square foot cabin in the north bay of the lake in 1997 and have been folded into the community. The governor is spotted in his motor boat, "sort of small," walking his dog, poking around the hardware store or buying groceries in the Stop and Shop in Litchfield.
"You do get some gawkers, but most people just let them be," said Thomas Weik, a member of the Morris Board of Selectman and Bantam Lake Authority.
The State Department of Environmental Protection monitors the lake's water quality and patrols the lake. At the moment, reducing invasive weeds is a top concern. The lake is a bit more than two miles long. Two-thirds of it is in Morris and the rest in Litchfield. Bantam is a borough of Litchfield, in the town's western portion; some lake addresses are in the Bantam borough.
Morris is by far the more rural of the two towns, with a four corners town center that has an elementary school, a library and town hall that share a building, a church, a seasonal ice cream shop, the deli, and a post office. Bantam is a section of Litchfield with its own zip code.
Litchfield's center is bigger and certainly better known for its country chic. True, the butchers at the Litchfield Locker Company pile cow hides out in front of the shop like Turkish rugs and customers can get tuna salad on white bread in the small luncheonette, but the center also houses fancy restaurants and markets, a book store, coffee shop, and several boutiques, including a Talbot's. And the streets surrounding the center feature carefully restored historic homes with manicured lawns. Women carrying Kate Spade bags and wearing Lilly Pulitzer shifts are a summer staple in Litchfield.
But what about Bantam Lake? The people who live here said the lake is less a see-and-be-seen vacation place than a respite from the social pressure cooker. For one thing, Bantam Lake tends toward the rustic. Many of the houses do not and cannot have a septic system, which means summer people contend with a privy or chemical toilet. And although in the past few years there have been several sales of houses for more than $1 million, even those properties are far from flashy. Frosted with snow, the bungalows and cottages look sturdy and practical, with nary a ginger-bread trim nor clipped boxwood hedge in sight. There's nothing showy about the social scene, either.
"It's mostly a place for families, sometimes friends, " said a woman who works in town hall, but who asked not to be identified. "It's dead during the week and usually quiet on the weekends."
But it will it remain so?
"The face of people on the lake is becoming more elite," said Ms. Clark, who was born and raised here. "There's been a huge influx of people coming in with a lot of money and buying up houses."
Indeed, the most significant change to come to Bantam Lake is its escalating real estate prices since 1997, the year the Rowlands bought their cottage and added cachet to a lake that had been largely the province of the working class. The house Mr. Rowland and his wife, Patricia, bought is a boxy, dark brown, wooden cottage. Yet Van Winkle Road is a desirable part of the lake because the homes are father apart. Mr. Rowland's is the last on the street and has a neighbor on one side only. Mr. Sigiel said it wasn't just coincidence that prices rose after the governor bought. 
"Also, the price of waterfront everywhere just went up stratospherically, " said Barbara Bigos, who is assessor for the towns of Morris and Salisbury. "At least this lake was somewhat affordable."
The same cottage the Rowlands bought for $110,000 in 1997 on leased land from White Memorial Foundation would sell for upward of $240,000 today, said Mr. Sigiel and Ms. Bigos. The trend for new buyers at Bantam Lake is to tear down the modest cottages and build a bigger house. It is a trend that alarms Mr. Sigiel.
"I don't want people who come here from different economies and pay top dollar for something to constantly raise the prices and drive out the working class," he said.
"New Yorkers and Jersey people, that's always been the case, " Mr. Weik said. "But most of the people are from Connecticut." And most of them are from Fairfield County, Ms. Bigos said.
But as prices rise, so have assessments and property taxes. Scott Petersen, who installs lightening rods and owns a family summer house on Marsh Point on the lake, said when his family bought the house in 1960 for $7,000, taxes were $600.
Today, they are $5,400.

HEADLINE: New London Neighbors Find It Best to Keep a Little Distance 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT COLLEGE'S effort to take over the management of the Lyman Allyn Art Museum, its neighbor here in New London, has ended where it began -- in court.
 The college and the museum have agreed to end an arrangement made five years ago under which the college, trying to expand its arts program, became the museum's trustee, or financial and administrative caretaker. The arrangement was made in New London Probate Court because the museum is governed by two trusts. 
 In October, the college returned to court, seeking to be removed as trustee and to be repaid $1.3 million of the $3.2 million it had spent on the museum. Under a new agreement, signed last Tuesday, control of the museum will be returned to an independent board, and the museum will pay the college $270,290. 
In addition, the agreement permits the college to redirect to itself $230,000 of donations made to the museum, and to keep an $87,851 bequest made to the museum. In total, the college will be paid $588,141.
The museum has also promised that for 30 years it will offer membership privileges to college students and faculty, and will provide space for functions and resources for college courses.
The agreement takes effect on June 30.
Officials from the college and the museum said they were satisfied with the new agreement.
Fleur Lawrence, president of the board at the museum, which will take over its administration, called the college's period as trustee "an experiment that was right for the 90's, in a different economic climate, and is notright for this time." 
She added that the museum had already raised $205,000 toward what it must pay the college.
Helen Regan, an education professor at the college who has been overseeing its effort to separate from the museum, said the college's original goal was "to help the museum rise up to a higher level of quality," but that "the financial agreement was not able to be sustained."
The museum, founded in 1926, was established by a trust under Harriet Allyn's will, and honors her father, Lyman, a merchant who was prominent in New London's whaling industry. Ms. Allyn's will, along with a trust set up in 1934 under the will of Virginia Palmer, a New London philanthropist, is the source of an endowment that has financed the museum. But in recent years, the income from the trusts has not come close to covering expenses.
Since its founding, the institution has amassed an eclectic collection of over 15,000 objects, ranging from African tribal art to antique dolls and dollhouses. It is perhaps most well known for its substantial holdings in American 19th-and 20th-century painting and decorative arts. 
For more than three decades, the museum's director was Edgar Mayhew, an art history professor at Connecticut College. After Mr. Mayhew retired, in the late 1980's, the museum went through two directors in quick succession. 
In the mid-1990's, the museum's accreditation from the American Association of Museums lapsed, potentially compromising its ability to get grants and donations. Failure to be accredited may also jeopardize efforts to borrow art work and obtain insurance for exhibitions.
By the late 1990's, the museum was in serious financial trouble, its buildings and grounds in noticeable decline. At that time, Claire Gaudiani was president of the college, whose campus is next door to the museum. Interested in improving the college's arts programs, she had the idea that the college should get more involved in the museum, she said in a telephone interview from New York City. She now holds a research position at Yale Law School.
"The strength of Connecticut College and the arts had been nationally recognized for many decades, and I believed it was in the best interest to build upon that alumni strength and stature and the work of the faculty," she said. 
In 1996, the college got the authority to manage the museum administratively, although not financially. That year, Charles Shepard, an art historian, became museum director. There was then only one other fulltime employee, Mr. Shepard said, adding that the other staff was paid hourly rates, with no benefits, and so morale was low.
Meanwhile, he said, the gift shop had closed; three galleries lacked proper lighting; there were few exhibitions; and limestone columns in the basement of the property's Deshon-Allyn house, where Harriet Allyn grew up, and which had been an exhibition site, were crumbling. To add to the overall decay, Oriental bittersweet had begun to choke most of the grounds, and much of the grass went uncut.
"It was a waist-deep jungle out there," said Mr. Shepard, who became director of the Fort Wayne Art Museum in Indiana in 2002. 
Ms. Regan explained the problems simply. "Its revenues were not sufficient to maintain it," she said.
A state bond had covered some improvements to the building, including a system for climate at the main museum, but the institution lacked the money even to run that system, Mr. Shepard said. 
Meanwhile, there were issues about the direction of the museum. Mr. Shepard said that Mr. Mayhew's philosophy was to have an eclectic collection, to be "a local mini-Met," referring to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. He said that he did not share that approach, and that he worked to mount shows that emphasized quality over eclecticism. "The whole mission was to bring quality to bear," he said.
He took down a longstanding exhibition of African art because the pieces were not of high quality, he said.
In 1998, the college sought to expand its arrangement with the museum and was appointed trustee. Since then, it has paid for more staff and increases in salaries; for the landscaping of the grounds; for renovations of the neo-classical building designed by Charles A. Platt that houses the museum, and of the Deshon-Allyn house, which now holds the doll and dollhouse collections; for new gallery lighting; for a new alarm system; and for a failed effort to open an exhibition space in downtown New London.
But as early as 1999, the overall financial commitment became too much for the college, Ms. Regan said. The museum's budget is currently more than $700,000; the annual interest income from the trusts is $200,000. Donations must make up the difference.
Although these contributions did not drop over the last five years, she said, the fear was that prospective donors would assume that the college was supporting the museum, and so would not give as much. If donations dried up, she said, the museum could become a drain on the college.
Ms. Regan added that the arrangement was problematic from the start because under the two trusts, the museum's mandate was to serve the general public of New London, and the college would not be free to control the programming as it wished. 
Christopher Steiner, an art historian whom the college hired to direct a museum studies certificate program, replaced Mr. Shepard, and will be the interim director until next July. He has increased public lectures and publicity, and planned new exhibitions, including one based on the former Nut Museum in Old Lyme that is scheduled to open in February.
As for the future of the museum, Mr. Steiner said, "Depending on who the next director is, as long as it remains a strong, vibrant museum, I see that as a positive."

The museum, founded in 1926 in honor of Lyman Allyn, a New London merchant shown above in a 19th-century oil by Nahum Ball Onthank, will now be governed by an independent museum board. (Photographs by C.M. Glover for The New York Times; portrait of Lyman Allyn is from the Lyman Allyn Art Museum)

HEADLINE: A Land Trust, Wealthy Donors, A Family Farm And a Big Problem 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH MAKER

 BODY:
THERE'S a country lane between two towns in northwest Connecticut that is postcard-perfect in its bucolic beauty. But lately, it has been the backdrop for a dispute that some see as between wealthy weekenders versus long-time local farming families.
 The two sides disagree abouthow a beef cattle farm on Town Line Road in Bridgewater, owned by the Bridgewater Land Trust, should be run and they disagree about the appearance of that farm. 
 Some donors to the land trust, who have given more than a $1 million each, argue that the trust isn't honoring their vision of how the property should be preserved, thereby risking future donations to the trust.
"We are treading a very tight rope here," said Kevin Alldred, president of the Bridgewater Land Trust, a nonprofit open space preservation group that's caught in the middle of the disagreement. "Anything we say or do is likely to seriously upset one half of the town or the other." 
It all centers on a 96-acre farm preserve on the road that divides Roxbury to the east and Bridgewater to the west. When word got out around four years ago about a possible plan to subdivide and develop the farm, a few Bridgewater weekenders decided to save the open space and donate a little over a million dollars each to the trust, which purchased the farm for $2.2 million in 2000.
The donors were Terry Fitzgerald, a Wall Street investor with Longbow Capital and his wife, Libby, who gave $1.125 million; William Rondina, owner of the Carlisle Collection, a women's clothing line, who gave $1.125 million, and Peter May, president and co-owner of Triarc Companies, a conglomerate of restaurant franchises, in Manhattan and his wife, Leni, who owned the Town Line Farm property at the time. They in effect donated about $1 million to the trust by offering to sell the farm for less than its $3.5 million market value.
"We were overjoyed," Mr. Alldred recalled. "It was the largest donation the land trust had ever received, and we were quite taken by the generosity of the donors." The donations enabled the land trust not only to purchase the property, but to beautifully restore the barn and farmhouse, he said.
But, the donation came with some strings attached for whomever farmed the land and lived in the house. The donors feel they have every right to tighten those strings now, three years later, by imposing new regulations that they said clarify their original intentions about the property and tenants. 
For the Fitzgeralds, who spend weekends at Grey Ledge, their Bridgewater estate just down the hill and across the street from the farm, the donation came with no hesitation. The couple had already acquired about 150 acres since they came to town 10 years ago, and preserving the farm would further protect their scenic vistas as well as expand the available territory for riding their horses, they said. 
"We thought we were doing something really nice for everyone in the area," said Ms. Fitzgerald after a recent Bridgewater Land Trust meeting, a tense gathering of board members and about 75 citizens at the local library. "I just can't believe things have gotten so contentious. It really hurts."
Soon after the land trust took ownership of the Town Line Farm Preserve, they formed a subcommittee to interview prospective farmers to lease the property. The subcommittee, comprising the Fitzgeralds, Bridgewater First Selectman Bill Stuart Sr., and Cheryl Johnson, a lawyer who was then president of the land trust, rejected several farmers before deciding on a couple from Massachusetts who also happened to be Mr. Stuart's son, Bill Stuart Jr., and his wife, Deb. Bill Stuart Jr. grew up in Bridgewater and spent most of his life farming cattle with his father. The couple and their two sons moved into the farm preserve during the summer of 2002. The farm is their only means of income.
All was fine the first year: Paying the land trust a monthly rent of $1,250, as the lease stipulated, the Stuarts went about their business of raising 120 head of beef cattle, maintaining the grounds, the 300-foot-long red barn, and the white 1842 farmhouse.
"I would wake up every morning and look out and say 'Thank you God, we are so blessed,"' Ms. Stuart said, choking back tears. "And now, it's like this cold, black cloud hanging over us. It's like having your dream-come-true evolve into a living nightmare."
The problems surfaced in the summer when Mr. Fitzgerald learned that the Stuarts had applied with the Roxbury Zoning Commission to operate a farm stand on the property. It would have been a 15-foot-by-20-foot area in an existing garage, where the couple planned to sell vegetables from their garden and beef.
Mr. Fitzgerald said he was angry that the couple didn't ask him or the other donors how they felt about having a farm stand there. A farm stand was never part of the original agreement, Mr. Fitzgerald said.
"This whole term 'farm stand' is a canard," Mr. Fitzgerald said. "What they propose is actually a highly specialized commercial retail venue," that, he added, would draw unwanted traffic to the area.
The Stuarts found another location for the farm stand across town. But, the donors were still concerned. 
"It's outlandish," Bill Stuart Jr. said at the land trust meeting in November. "We've found another location for the farm stand, end of story. So why are we even here?"
The Fitzgeralds said they worry that the farm stand issue may arise again, and they have other concerns about the appearances of the property. For instance, among developments they didn't like were the "Stuart Family Farm" sign that was placed on the property; the golf cart that the Stuarts' two sons, Will, 9, and Christian, 8, use to ride around the property; the all terrain vehicle that Bill Stuart Jr. sometimes rides to check fences and livestock on the huge property; and, the 120 head of cattle that seems excessive to the Fitzgeralds.
At the time of the gift, the donors' original written intentions stated that "the land be used for agricultural purposes in perpetuity," specifying that the crops be restricted to hay and livestock be restricted to beef cattle or sheep. But the donors said it is what they didn't stipulate specifically that is just as important. 
"I would submit that this case will set a precedent," said Mr. Fitzgerald, who serves on the Roxbury Land Trust and is co-chairman of a program called Save Our Farms that has raised nearly $7 million over the past two years to preserve about 800 acres of farmland in the area. "You have got to respect and uphold the intentions of the individual donors, or donations will be unlikely in the future." Among other things, the Fitzgeralds' and the other donors' clarifications of their original intentions define what they call a "passive agricultural operation" on the property. They want to prohibit farm stands or any kind of development; limit the number of cattle to 35; limit the farm equipment used; prohibit all-terrain vehicles, golf carts or other motorized recreational vehicles on the property; allow only hay to be grown on and sold from the property; allow only one annual auction of cattle or sheep; prohibit advertising in any form, including signs on the property or ads in newspapers or radio.
Another specific stipulation in the donors' clarifications stated, "As it is impossible to envision future requests or unforeseen circumstances, all activities not explicitly identified in this document are inconsistent with donor intent and should not be undertaken or allowed."
Deb Stuart said that she and her family are "apparently not classy enough for the Fitzgeralds.
"They think the next thing we'll do is put a clothesline up, and an old mattress with springs popping out of it on the porch," she added.
Mr. Rondina declined to comment, and the Mays were traveling and could not be reached. But Mr. Fitzgerald explained, "We believe that the land trust accepted our donation with explicit and implicit commitments that the property be preserved as it was at the time, and that the nature of the agricultural activity not be expanded or altered.
"This is not a matter of personality, it's a matter of principal," Mr. Fitzgerald added. "We have a situation where the Stuarts have changed the rules so they can capitalize on the full economic potential of the farm" by proposing to run a farm stand. "It is not the responsibility of the land trust to ensure the economic viability of the farm. This is about farmland preservation, not farming preservation."
The Stuarts, however, argued that they haven't changed any rules; that farm stands are a permitted agricultural use under Connecticut statutes and under local zoning laws. 
Some residents saw the newly written intentions as hypocritical since the Fitzgeralds themselves have 35 head of cattle, operate a farm stand in the summer, have several signs on their property, and drive an all terrain vehicle on their land.
Mr. Fitzgerald said their situation is different because theirs is private property, not owned by a land trust. And their farm stand is a charitable operation open only in August, run by the Fitzgerald's two sons, William, 10, and Robert, 8, and 20 percent of the proceeds got to the Bridgewater and Roxbury Land Trusts.
At the meeting, a petition signed by 220 area residents supporting the tenant farmers was submitted, stating that the proposed restrictions would force them to leave the farm. 
But Jean Bandler, a resident of Bridgewater, urged the land trust board to "stand by the donors and honor their intentions. Failure to do this will lead down a very slippery and dangerous slope."
In other words: do what the donors ask, or lose future donations.
"We've got not only the future of this farm at stake," said Mr. Alldred, the land trust president, "but the future of our ability to preserve the rural character of this town. It's a highly volatile issue."
According to State Representative Clark Chapin, who was recently named Legislator of the Year by the Connecticut Farm Bureau Association, this kind of fracas is becoming increasingly common and is partly to blame for the fact that Connecticut farmland is disappearing at the rate of 9,000 acres a year.
"This is a classic case of competing forces when it comes to agriculture in the state of Connecticut," Mr. Chapin said. "People do want to preserve land and scenic vistas, but they don't want to offer any concessions to farmers. If people want to make a genuine effort to preserve farmland, they've got to make the same effort to preserve farming. You have to make allowances for certain activities that are key to the industry, otherwise the farmer has no chance. You can't just freeze the picture of the farm in time and expect it to stay looking like a farm with nobody farming it."
The land trust has formed a subcommittee to decide how to handle the matter and expects to issue a decision by Christmas.

HEADLINE: A Ban, Sort Of 

BYLINE:  By GEORGINA GUSTIN

 BODY:
IN one Connecticut bar recently, a bartender served drinks to a row of customers as they tipped their cigarettes into plastic ashtrays, filling the air with smoke.
 In another bar, another bartender also served customers, but the bar stood empty of ashtrays and the air was smoke-free. 
 Both places had all the makings of the classic watering hole - the bottles of liquor, the beer taps, the regulars perching on stools. But, at least for now, that other atmospheric bar ingredient, smoke, is legal in one place and not the other.
Following the lead of other states, including New York, Connecticut lawmakers overwhelmingly approved a law earlier this year banning smoking in all restaurants and bars throughout the state. But there's a difference in Connecticut, one that has customers and restaurateurs perplexed and a little angry, and some legislators pushing to tweak the new rules. 
The law is taking effect in two parts. As of Oct. 1, smoking was banned in restaurants, including those with separate bar areas, and owners were required to put up "no smoking" signs. Then, on April 1, 2004, bars have to follow suit.
The lag time between the restaurant smoke ban and the bar ban has Connecticut restaurateurs, many of whom depend on their bar business more than their dining patrons, angry as they watch their regulars file out the door to places where they can still light up. And while the ban is a victory for public health that has delighted nonsmokers and even improved dining business at some restaurants, many in the state's service industry see it as flawed, inconsistent and unfair.
"I used to close down at 1 a.m.," said Nick Jhilal, manager of the Bear and Grill in Fairfield, who estimated that he had lost 30 to 40 percent of his bar patrons to bars where they can still smoke. "Now I close down at 9:30. The next three hours are dead."
In Connecticut there is a range of permits that allow places to serve alcohol. The bulk of permits are issued to restaurants, which serve food as well as liquor, and to bars, which get what is called a "cafe" license and are allowed to serve liquor with food on the side, if they choose.
Restaurants throughout the state, especially those with closed-off bar areas, are being hard-hit by the ban, and the economic effects have some lawmakers wondering about the wisdom of the new rules. 
"This legislation damaged the marketplace," said Simon A. Flynn, president of the Connecticut Restaurant Association, who said he had heard from dozens of restaurant owners, one of whom said he lost $10,000 in the first month of the ban. "It doesn't make sense. The bars are luxuriating in this inequity."
In the meantime, many restaurateurs are simply looking the other way as smokers light up because they can't afford to lose their business.
"People leave, people just walk out," said Tina McManus, a bartender and waitress at Black Rock Castle in Bridgeport, which is in a strip of bars and restaurants lining Fairfield Avenue through Fairfield and into Westport. "The whole law is ridiculous."
Ms. McManus, a smoker herself, estimated that 90 percent of the restaurant's customers are smokers and many are going to more smoke-friendly places. That's a financial hit many restaurants apparently aren't willing to take. "They're cheating," Ms. McManus said of other restaurants in the area. "They have to.
"I don't like smelling smoke. I don't like it on my clothes. But I like walking home with a bundle of cash," Ms. McManus added, noting that smokers who are allowed to smoke tend to linger longer and buy more drinks. "If you did a survey of employees, no one would agree with the ban. You're taking money out of our pockets."
Under the new law, people can be fined $99 if they are caught smoking in a no-smoking establishment. The business itself is only required to post "no smoking" signs and can be fined $99 if it does not, but it is not fined if customers are actually smoking. The only people who can issue the $99 tickets are the police, and police departments around the state said they have more pressing issues than tracking errant smokers.
"I wish I had the time to proactively check restaurants," said Louis DeCarlo, chief of the Stamford Police Department. "We're taking the tack that most police departments are. We're only responding to complaints."
According to the State's Liquor Control Division, which issues liquor permits, the license of a restaurant or bar can be revoked by the state for violating the ban. But that would likely happen only if the police or a customer complained to the state, prompting the liquor commission to investigate. And even then it is not clear what would set off the commission's inquiry -- an establishment's failure to post signs, as the new law requires, or its failure to actually pluck cigarettes from smokers' mouths.
"We would expect a licensed permit holder to comply with the state law, and if it was found not to be, we would investigate," said John Suchy, director of the division. Then, "Based on our determination we could take regulatory action."
When asked how many times an establishment would have to violate the law, or in what way, before the commission took action, Mr. Suchy said: "It's going to be on a case-by-case basis. I'm not going to say what the commission might do." 
Local departments of public health, which issue food permits to restaurants, also do not have a direct enforcement role, although they can revoke a food license for repeated violations of the ban and can subtract points from annual inspections. Under the new law, though, it's not clear how many violations it would take for a health department to rescind a license. 
"It says violations, plural," said Michael Lauzier of the American Lung Association of Connecticut.
Some places are willing to take the risk.
"What are they going to do, have a smoking force, like the Gestapo?" said Richard Ball, owner of Jeremiah Donovan's on Washington Street in South Norwalk. "Enforcing the thing's a joke. That's a full-time job."
Mr. Ball said the ban had been a mixed blessing for his business.
"I know there are people who used to come in every night that are going someplace else for now," he said. "But my lunch business is up 25 percent. I think it's very positive. It's a nasty habit and this is what the state is trying to tell you."
Nonetheless, Mr. Ball said, late at night, after the dining rush is over, "People can light up and I probably wouldn't say anything."
Jeremiah Donovan's is among many of the state's restaurants who said business has improved since Oct. 1.
"Actually, it's kind of interesting," said John Black, a bartender at Dunville's Westport. "Our dinner sales have gone up. People are starting to look at us as more of a restaurant than a bar now."
Still, the change hasn't pleased everyone and some lawmakers are responding.
Under the original version of the bill introduced earlier this year, the General Assembly's Public Health Committee adopted a provision that would allow separate smoking rooms in bars, but the idea was dropped. Now, Representative Art Feltman, Democrat of Hartford and House chairman of the committee, said he would support changing the law to include that provision again.
"If there is a huge drop in revenues at bars," Mr. Feltman said, "I'd be open to that proposal."
In early November, Gov. John G. Rowland told a reporter that he believed restaurants and bars should be allowed to establish separate smoking rooms, but Mr. Feltman said he didn't feel a change should go that far. "It should never extend to restaurants," he said.
Dean Pagani, a spokesman for the governor, said Mr. Rowland's remarks were made in an off-hand way. "It got really overblown. He was really just expressing his opinion," Mr. Pagani said. "He's really leaving it up to the Legislature He has no intention of proposing that."
So, for the time being, restaurants are adjusting to the ban and bars are gearing up for what could be a big financial blow. The only establishments that will clearly see a rise in smokers' business are private clubs, like boat clubs or some social clubs, which have different liquor licenses that will allow smoking even after the ban.
"Our sense, from a number of different restaurateurs is that part of the competition they face now is from private clubs," said Mr. Flynn of the restaurant association. "What we're hearing is that clubs are developing different categories of memberships, like associate memberships, to allow more members. Individuals that might not qualify under the rules of membership are now eligible."
At some private clubs, employees rejected the idea of a smoking ban.
"This is not Cuba," said David Duncan, a bartender at a Veterans of Foreign Wars post in Norwalk. "Next thing you know people are going to be telling you to be home at 11 o'clock at night."
But this raises another issue, restaurant owners said. If the bill was intended to protect the health of employees in bars and restaurants, don't employees in clubs deserve the same protection? 
"Are they protected under the law or not?" asked Mr. Jhilal of the Bear and Grill, who said he has hired lawyers to look into whether the law violates the 14th amendment of the Constitution, which guarantees equal protection.
"If it is a public health issue, then it should be a statewide ban," Mr. Flynn said. "If they can't do that, they should retreat to a position whereby the only ban on smoking in the state is in dining rooms."
Or smokers can find refuge in Rhode Island, where smoking is still allowed in restaurants and bars, or perhaps New York, where some lawmakers are attempting to roll back a ban that went into effect in July.
The bill, co-sponsored by Republican Assemblymen Howard Mills and Matthew Mirones would allow bars to buy "smoking licenses" for $100 a year.
"I think people should make their own choices, and I was very concerned about the bars in my district that are going out of business," Mr. Mills said, noting that his district abuts New Jersey, where smokers are spilling over the state border to bars that still permit smoking. 
"This is based on personal liberty and freedom of choice issues," Mr. Mills added. "I'm not even a smoker myself."

HEADLINE: BOOKS; 
It's Not a Labor of Love, but They Love It Anyway

BYLINE:  By PETER BOODY

DATELINE: Bridgehampton 

 BODY:
FOR some, retirement may be about golf, gardening, grandchildren and a smug satisfaction about a life well lived. But that was not on the agenda for Barbara and Warren H. Phillips of Bridgehampton. When he retired nearly 13 years ago at 65 as chief executive officer and publisher of The Wall Street Journal, and she gave up a teaching and freelance writing career that she had persevered in while raising two daughters, they wanted a new challenge.
 It had to be something that would use their skills. They also wanted to keep active in the world, even as they left Manhattan for full-time residence at their weekend place overlooking the bridge across Sagg Pond, between Bridgehampton and Sagaponack. One thought was buying a local newspaper, but none were for sale. 
 The idea they came up with was to found Bridge Works Publishing Company, which today has about 85 hardback and paperback titles to its credit and lately is averaging 12 a year, mostly fiction. Its next release, due in January, is a murder mystery set in New Jersey during the British occupation in the Revolutionary War. 
 The Phillipses run the company out of their home; Mrs. Phillips is the editor, and Mr. Phillips handles the business side. They have a part-time editorial staff of two. 
"You must be crazy" to go into fiction publishing, people told them, Mrs. Phillips recalled, in a recent interview in the cozy study of their home. But they have had success with Bridge Works. Although they usually sell only a few thousand copies of each title in hardback, they have landed paperback and foreign reprint contracts as well as some television and movie options.
 "It can pay off," said Mr. Phillips with a laugh, as if it were a miracle.
 For example, Ballantine Books bought the paperback rights to "Patty Jane's House of Curl," a novel by Lorna Landvik published by Bridge Works in 1995. It has sold more than a quarter of a million copies, with proceeds of about $200,000 going to Bridge Works. 
 One of the company's biggest success stories is that of Alan Isler, who had given up trying to sell his novel, "Prince of West End Avenue," when the Phillipses accepted it. Published in 1994, the novel was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle award that year. Penguin put out its paperback edition. Mr. Isler has since had a book published by Viking.
 Another success is Tom Perrotta, whose first book, "Bad Haircut: Stories of the Seventies," a collection of short stories, was also published in 1994 by Bridge Works. It was reprinted by Berkley, part of Penguin, which signed him on for more books, including one that is supposed to be made into a film with Reese Witherspoon, Mrs. Phillips said.
 "We don't mind being the farm team and see them succeed with bigger money than we can afford," she said. 
 Mrs. Phillips grew up on the eastern shore of Virginia, and graduated from the University of Virginia with a degree in English. Mr. Phillips was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., and grew up in Queens. He graduated from Queens College with a degree in economics. They met at a cocktail party in the early 1950's in London. He was The Journal's bureau chief, and she worked in an office job for the United States Office of Naval Research. They were married in London a year later.
 In the mid-1950s, after The Journal had brought Mr. Phillips back to New York and the couple was raising a family in Manhattan, she got a master's degree from New York University and began teaching at a private school in Brooklyn, as well as editing and writing as a freelancer.
 They moved to Chicago, where Mr. Phillips ran The Journal's Midwest edition for seven years, and then returned to New York. Mr. Phillips was named publisher and chief executive officer of the newspaper in 1975. He had worked for The Journal in one capacity or another since college.
 "We had a long and successful professional life and then suddenly you decided to retire," Mrs. Phillips said.
 "I was 65," he interrupted.
 "And we decided we would start another profession, the two of us," she said.
 He continued, "It had to be a shared interest, something to do with the world of words and ideas, a world that dealt with interesting people -- newspaper people, authors, writers...."
 "And you had never had any experience with any kind of writing other than newspaper work," she said.
 "Barbara had written book reviews, freelanced for Vogue and New York magazine," he said.
 "I taught English," she said. "I knew all the great 20th-century-and-before writers. I thought it would be fun to bring Warren into it because his interest in writing and reading was...."
 "Strictly journalistic," he offered.
 "Except for reading 'Editor & Publisher,"' she said.
 "The best thing is she raised my horizons," he said with a half smile.
 It was obvious they had been a team for a long time.
 They looked into buying The Southampton Press, but it was not for sale. Talks with The East Hampton Star went nowhere.
 "We were just brainstorming," Mrs. Phillips said, when they got the idea of forming their own publishing company. The South Fork already had Bill Henderson's Pushcart Press in Amagansett and Martin and Judith Shepherd's Permanent Press in Sag Harbor. And New York friends in the publishing business warned them of its pitfalls.
 But from the beginning, things worked out well. In 2000, they sold the company to Rowman & Littlefield Publishing Group of Lanham, Md., which owns the distributor they use. The Phillipses said they sold the business because their children, two daughters, have their own careers, and there was no succession plan.
 Under the arrangement with Rowman & Littlefield, though, they continue to choose and edit the books. Mr. Phillips still handles much of the marketing, including getting the book reviews that, along with word of mouth and local booksellers, make a book sell. 
 Mr. Phillips said they learned early on how important book reviews were with their 1993 book, "The Hard Way: The Odyssey of a Weekly Newspaper Editor" by Alexander B. Brook. The book, a memoir by Mr. Brook of his life as editor and publisher of a weekly newspaper in Maine, "was reviewed up and down the country," Mr. Phillips said. That made it "a really good launch," he said, adding that because it was about the newspaper businesses, editors wanted to review it.
 "It helped that you knew everybody," Mrs. Phillips added.
 She and their staff, Alexandra Shelley, the deputy editorial director, and Dorothea Halliday, the office manager, pore through more than 3,000 submissions a year, better than 60 a week, she said. It is exhausting work, and Mrs. Phillips said it was not a labor of love.
 "I don't think Warren and I ever have gone into anything as dilettantes," she said. "We wanted to do something that would keep us interested in the world. We haven't regretted a moment of it even though we work so hard."
 She added: "People ask us why. If we were not doing this, we'd be sitting in some nursing home reading."
 "My golf game would be better," Mr. Phillips said.

They started the company after he retired as chief executive officer and publisher of The Wall Street Journal. (Photo by Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Working Relationships 

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
IT is, of course, all in the family. 
 Take the the father and his two sons who run a gynecological practice in Sleepy Hollow. Or the small brother-sister hair-removal empire in Manhattan and Scarsdale. Or the father-son window-washing concern in Larchmont. Or the husband-wife dental practice in Mount Kisco, not to mention the family-owned string of restaurants in Manhattan and Westchester. 
 If the business of America is, in fact, business, then the bulk of the country is family-owned or family-controlled, and Westchester is no exception. Family-run businesses are a fundamental part of the economy, both nationally and on the local level. 
A family business might be a ma-and-pa grocery, a one-person business or a publicly traded company managed by outsiders but influenced by a founder's heirs. The greater part of America's wealth, more than half, is tied up in family-owned business, according to figures from the Family Firm Institute in Boston, a professional organization that advises and consults on family businesses. 
Locally, said Marsha Gordon, the president and chief executive officer of the Business Council of Westchester, which is the new name for the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, there are no precise figures, but family-run businesses are significant players in the county's economy, she said. 
"They tend to be longstanding businesses, and they often give back the most because they have been so intimately involved," she said. "When it comes to grass roots support, community organization or money for firehouses or little leagues, there are some corporations and large organizations that do a lot, but family businesses are normally in the lead." 
To be sure, family business is not all roses. Unity of purpose among family members can be great, but the complications of family issues on top of the complexities of business can make family businesses extremely stressful. More than 30 percent of family-owned businesses make it to the second generation, according to the Family Firm Institute, but just 12 percent make it to the third generation, and only 3 percent to the fourth.
Paraphrasing Tolstoy, it is safe to say all family business are alike in some ways. Very often, they start with one person and draw others in, as did a hair-removal business founded by Cindy Barshop, who lives in Manhattan. Looking for a bikini waxing, Ms. Barshop, a former I.B.M. saleswoman, went to a hair-removal salon in Manhattan. While she was impressed with the industry's pulsed light technology, Ms. Barshop was awed by the salon's four-month waiting list. 
She decided to open her own hair salon, using her initials in calling it Completely Bare. That first place was on 18th Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Her parents, Morty and Ruth Barshop from Wantagh on Long Island, helped her paint that first building the night before the opening and her brother, Howard, also painted and helped out. 
With a background in sales and technology, Ms. Barshop took to the business's operations and promotion, but she needed help on the financial end, and Howard, who lives in Tuckahoe and who was working in finance, gave her all his free time. Then came plans for a second salon, this one in Scarsdale.
Ms. Barshop said that the two balanced each other in talents and in temperaments. "I was always the rebel," Ms. Barshop said, "Howard was the nice one. He is just better at interacting with people, dealing with vendors, dealing with so much. I don't shut up in meetings, but he knows when to tell me to be quiet."
Mr. Barshop agreed. "I'm calm and collected," he said. "Everyone likes me. My sister is hard-nosed, the bad cop. We play good-cop/bad-cop with vendors a lot." 
Planning the Scarsdale location, she asked her brother to be an equal partner.
"If I came in full time," Mr. Barshop said. "I couldn't work in the same little place as my sister." Completely Bare now has three locations, with plans for a fourth, and Ms. Barshop said the family nature of the business was a key to its growth. 
"It would have gotten off the ground without Howard," Ms. Barshop said, "but it would not have been pretty." 
The two, she added, were not necessarily close as children, only growing more so after college. Their parents are thrilled to see them working well together, he said. "They think we're the greatest kids," he said. "They just want to see us married."
A different kind of empire was begun in the Sleepy Hollow Medical group, said Dr. Lawrence Mendelowitz, now a partner at the group. He grew up in a community where his father, Dr. Stanley Mendelowitz, now 78, and his uncle, Dr. Eugene Saberski, who died last year, had a well-respected obstetrics and gynecology practice, started by Dr. Saberski in in 1946 and joined by Dr. Stanley Mendelowitz in 1955. Joining them seemed the natural order of things, he said. 
"Because of my father and uncle," said Dr. Lawrence Mendelowitz, 53, now a partner at the Sleepy Hollow Medical Group, "I always had this positive disposition toward the profession. Joining the practice was the culmination of that." Dr. Lawrence Mendelowitz added that, after medical school, he might have pursued a fellowship and gone into a more academic setting, had it not been for the opportunity to join the family practice. He's been there ever since. 
His younger brother, Dr. Mark Mendelowitz, 47, joined the family practice in 1986 and eventually became a full partner, before leaving to pursue music education in Spain in 1999. "When I was younger," Dr. Mark Mendelowitz said, "I wasn't thinking as much as an individual. I was following a path and it was a good path, but still a path that I followed." 
Dr. Mark Mendelowitz said that he needed to find a balance in his life between his career as a doctor and his lifelong interest in music. Such a balance, he added, can be trickier to find in a family business where, he said, you step into an existing structure rather than creating one yourself. "It was a matter of finding out 'Who am I?"' he said, "of separating from Sleepy Hollow Medical Group and being not just another Mendelowitz, but also Mark." Dr. Mark Mendelowitz, back from Spain, is currently working part time at the family practice, and also working at Ossining Open Door, a clinic, while pursuing his classical guitar interests on the side. 
A different kind of father-son business began when Sam Weintraub, now 83, bought a window-washing route in 1948. He washed commercial and residential windows, mostly in Larchmont and Mamaroneck, and his son, Michael, would work with him on the occasional weekend and school holiday.
But Michael, 51, went to college and then to a career as a commodity trader. He never looked back. Or, at least, he almost never looked back. "I always used to say to my father, 'Don't sell the business until you talk to me first,"' he said. "I was half-joking, but I always thought if I got laid off, at least I'd have an ace in the hole." 
Then, about 20 years into his career, Mr. Weintraub did get laid off. "It was a Thursday in 1992," he said, "and I started to freak out. By Monday I was washing windows." Whether it was temporary or not was not clear, Mr. Weintraub added, but he stayed because working for a family business close to home, helped him better care for his son, Eric, 19, who has been chronically ill since infancy with severe anemia. 
Working for two decades outside the business, Larchmont Window Cleaners, was essential to his happiness in working within it, Michael Weintraub said. "When you are washing windows in the morning," he said, "you see everyone with their jackets and suits on, going to Manhattan to go to restaurants and, if you haven't done it yourself, you'd think your missing out on something big. But I've done that and I've been on business trips for two to three weeks. It's just not that glamorous.
"The fantasy is always better than the reality," he said, but it's the getting away from the family business that allowed him to understand that, plus the ability to prove to himself and others that he has talents and knowledge beyond the family business. 
Though he said he was always close to his father, he does have a recommendation to all family business, whether they work on ladders or in board rooms. "An in-house psychologist," said the younger Mr. Weintraub, who took it over the business entirely two months ago when his father retired. 
Echoing that thought in a different way, at the Kellogg School of Management in Evanston, Ill., Lloyd Shefsky, the co-director of the Center for Family Enterprises, said that taking a business to the second generation and beyond is no easy task. There are many advantages to a family business: from the trust factor to the sixth sense that is developed from a lifetime's exposure to the inner workings of a business to the particular talents held in common among management. 
Successful family businesses can go on for generations, a fact that was highlighted last year in an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society called "Family Matters: Century-Old New York City Businesses." (The New York Times, which has been controlled by the Ochs-Sulzberger family since 1896, was not included in the show.) 
But not all family businesses are fortunate enough to live that long. Famous food fights have split the Zabar, Balducci and Manganaro families in the city; farther afield, the Disney empire has been in the news lately with the offspring of the famous Walt Disney at odds with company management. 
Families often have fissures, the sorts of things that are hard to ignore if everyone is spending time in the same storefront. In a family business, emotions can become charged and results can be perilous, experts say. 
"Much of what you find in a family business," Mr. Shefsky said, "you'll find in any business, but to the Nth degree. It's always an expansion, an exaggeration of what normally goes on in business." 
Kathryn Rudie Harrigan, the Henry R. Kravis, professor of business leadership at the Columbia School of Business, said family business can be complicated by perceptions of favoritism, real and imagined, by family members and others in the business. She called it the "idiot nephew factor." It can, she said, be very frustrating "to know the top is blocked by a nephew they think is a blockhead." A dim but favored nephew can be trouble, as can rivalries between siblings or even jealousies between spouses. Ellen Holliday and Charles Azzaretti, who met at Columbia Dental School in the late 1970's and bonded, in part, over a shared vision about how patients should be treated. Though they did their residencies separately, they eventually married, moved to Brewster and opened their own practice together in Mount Kisco. 
Dr. Holliday said that she needed to learn not to be competitive with her husband. "Some patients like one of us better than the other and in the beginning it could really bother me," she said. "But there are so many intangibles involved, so many personality issues, that I had to learn to not worry about it, to realize that it all goes in the same pot." 
The arrangement has advantages that are both big and small, Dr. Holliday said. One spouse can cover a patient emergency for the other if there is a commitment involving one of their two children. Their receptionist can schedule their entire lives. "She's basically mine and my husband's wife," Dr. Holliday said. 
There are negatives, like the difficulty finding coverage when they go on family vacations, but when asked whether they spend too much time together, Dr. Holliday said that the separate treatment rooms are a help. They also say they have complimentary talents that help them work well as husband and wife and also as business partners. 
Dr. Holliday said: "He is very interested in elaborate new dental procedures and continuing education in implants and root canal therapies. I'm more oriented toward the business part of the practice. I know what's in the bank account. He has a vague idea." 
Many family businesses are much bigger than this one. For example, Strauss Paper, a Port Chester provider of janitorial and paper supplies with revenues in the area of $35 million and 100 employees, was started by Henry Strauss, who escaped Nazi Germany in the 1930's and began selling cleaning products out of his car. The company is now owned by Stewart Strauss and Joyce Strauss Jonap, Henry's children. A host of family members work there, including Mrs. Jonap's husband, Bob. The business was recently inducted into the county's business Hall of Fame.
Mrs. Jonap said that the fact that they are a family business is a natural selling point, because it engenders good will among customers, but managing a family business is not all roses.
"Like any business," Stewart Strauss said, "as it gets bigger, it doesn't get easier. And in a family business, it can be more complicated because there are more family members involved." 
The key, he said, are formalized discussions of roles, whether those discussions take place outside the board of directors or with the business consultants brought in. 
And when all that talk and defining of roles doesn't work, and there are fights? 
"We know to take a deep breath," Mrs. Jonap said. "And then go for a walk." 
One of the best-known family businesses in the area is a restaurant empire that started with a $1,300 purchase of a luncheonette in Astoria, Queens. The founder, John Livanos, a 67-year-old Greek immigrant, has become one of the most successful restaurateurs in the area, now joined by two sons and a daughter. The family owns two City Limits Diners in White Plains, one in Stamford, the Cafe Meze in Hartsdale and two Manhattan restaurants: Molyvos and Oceana. 
The Livanos children grew up in whatever restaurants their father owned at the time, . Mr. Livanos said his children were always welcome to join his business, but he had one demand: college first. 
Mr. Livanos said that when his sons Nick, now 44, and Bill, now 40, went into the business he was focused on traditional 24-hour-a day, 7-day-a-week diners, and they wanted to take it in a new direction. "They told me they loved the business, but wanted to go more upscale," Mr. Livanos said. "They didn't want to stay in a 24/7 diner, which is a rough world. I heard what they wanted and it was something I wanted too." 
The family opened Livanos, an upscale restaurant on the Central Avenue site where a City Limits diner currently is. But it was a mistake, said Mr. Livanos, too big a restaurant for such food. The family eventually converted it into the successful City Limits diner. 
When Corina Livanos, 33, graduated from the University of Rhode Island in 1992, she had no intention of joining the family business. But Oceana, a seafood restaurant, was opening at 55 East 54th Street, and a brother asked her to help out temporarily. 
"I know how demanding the restaurant business is," Ms. Livanos said, "so I told my brother I'd give it until Christmas. Embarrassingly, I've been here ever since." She said that as well as she gets along with her siblings, their working together is successful, in part, because of the separate locations, a thought echoed by Bill Livanos, who said they all have separate areas of expertise. For John Livanos, the success of the restaurants gives him energy, he said, as does the opportunity to work with his three children. It's just knowing that, together, they have built something that can sustain the family for years to come. "These are going to be their places," Mr. Livanos said. 

Family Ties? Put It in Writing. Get a Third Party.
AS always, much of the performance of a business is determined by individual managers' abilities, whether they are family members or not, and the vagaries of the business cycle. While sure-fire steps to succeed in a family business have yet to be invented, experts suggest that some measures can make the odds for success more favorable. 
Formal communication is the key, experts agree. A family's tendency to be casual in communication or to assume that things are understood are a major enemy, said Eugene Muscat, the director of the Gellert Foundation Family Business Center at the University of San Francisco. 
"For a family business to succeed," he said, "you always have to make the implicit explicit." This means job descriptions, a written overview of responsibilities and compensation, everything from tasks to salaries to hours, he said. "It's something hardly anyone in a family business has, but everyone needs," he said. "Sometimes Uncle Giorgio has always been making the same amount, but no one knows if he's overpaid or underpaid." Beyond that, maybe Cousin Susie always charges her car expenses and repairs to the business, while Cousin Jo thinks her Mercedes should come out of her pocketbook. Direct communication and written agreements help. 
For a small business a council of outside advisers should be created and for a large business an outside board is important, with both providing external voices. 
"They have to be people who can tell the patriarch and matriarch the things the children can't always tell them," said Mr. Muscat, who added that older generations classically have problems standing back or letting go of their businesses so the next generation can take over. Older generations often have problems spending on technologies that the younger generation wants.
Sometimes business decisions come down to a choice between what's best for the business and what's best for the family. "When push comes to shove between lifestyle and profits," he said, "a family business will almost always come down on the side of lifestyle." Marek Fuchs
