HEADLINE: EUROPEAN UNION CAN'T REACH DEAL ON CONSTITUTION 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13 

 BODY:
The leaders of 25 current and future members of the European Union failed to reach agreement on Saturday on a draft constitution, stumbling on a problem familiar to Americans: how to apportion power among large and small states.
 At issue was a proposal to discard a voting system agreed upon three years ago that gave Spain, a member of the union, and Poland, which joins next year, almost as much voting weight each as Germany, which has more than twice the population of either. Spain and Poland insisted on retaining the expanded rights. 
 Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, called the summit meeting "largely a failure," and said, "We don't have a consensus on a constitution here because one or another country put the European ideal behind national interest." 
Officially, the leaders said they would meet to try again next year. But the failure touched off bitter recriminations that underscored differences between current and soon-to-be members of the union. The war in Iraq also played a part: the deep divisions in "old" and "new" Europe over whether to go along with the United States' military action contributed to the wedges driving the leaders apart.
France's president, Jacques Chirac, said the failure galvanized his interest in creating a smaller union in the form of a "pioneer group" -- perhaps of the union's six founding countries, but open to others. He framed it as something that would accelerate integration. "It would be a motor that would set an example," he said at a news conference after the talks. "It would allow Europe to go faster, better."
But others read it as a move toward scaling back Europe's unification. Mr. Schroder, acknowledging the temptation to do so, said, "We will work that it not happen." 
Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, chairman of the talks, agreed. "I am not a partisan of the idea of six countries," he said.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who had sought unsuccessfully to soften the Spanish and Polish positions, said, "It is in my view entirely sensible that we take the time to get it right." He added, "To look at this in sort of apocalyptic terms is, I think, rather misguided." 
Poland's prime minister, Leszek Miller, left Brussels and was expected to call a cabinet meeting to discuss the outcome, Polish diplomats said. 
The meeting was not without its successes. On Friday, the leaders took a first important step toward striking a deal on the constitution's draft text, the subject of almost two years of discussion, when they agreed unanimously to a common defense policy that included planning abilities independent of NATO.
The constitution is considered crucial in light of the coming enlargement, by which the union, which began as a customs union of Germany, France, Italy, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, will become a 25-member club, bringing into its embrace many former East Bloc states, including Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovenia.
"The striking thing is that 95 percent of the issues are largely resolved," said Kevin Featherstone of the European Institute at the London School of Economics.
He said it was the very fact that agreements had been reached in most areas that had narrowed the room for the usual horse trading that lies at the heart of European compromises. With little else to decide, the voting rights issue became "crystal clear."
But he also said the stewardship of the talks might have contributed to the failure. "Berlusconi has this putting-your-foot-in-it tendency," he said.
As with the American leadership in Philadelphia in the 1780's, Europe's leaders are acting because they recognize that the challenges facing an enlarged union require more efficient government structures. Recent moves, including the introduction of the euro and the creation of a central bank, have fueled the drive beyond simple economic integration toward common policies in defense and foreign affairs.
The analogy with the United States, which moved in the 1780's from a confederation to a stronger national government under the Constitution, has not escaped the Europeans. When Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former French president and chairman of the convention that framed the draft constitution, left for vacation last summer, he took along a copy of David McCullough's best-selling biography of John Adams, the author of the Massachusetts Constitution, the oldest such text still in use.
Mr. McCullough said by phone from his home in Massachusetts that in Philadelphia, "all the small states were afraid of the large states; they feared they would take the ball and run with it." To provide equal weight in the councils of power, the founding fathers created the Senate, where all states are equally represented. "They called it the balancing wheel," he said.
Europe's leaders toyed in the past with the idea of transforming the Council of Europe into a kind of senate. But the idea was discarded in favor of a voting system agreed upon three years ago in Nice, France, that gave mid-sized countries like Poland and Spain almost as many votes each in the European Council as heavyweight Germany.
Poland and Spain are now relatively isolated, because the Nice system has been jettisoned in favor of an arrangement known as the double majority, which seeks to assure the rights of smaller states by defining a voting majority as at least half of the member states representing at least 60 percent of the total population.
Poland's foreign minister, Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz, had dug in his heels on Saturday morning. "If it is not possible to agree on the change today we shall wait," he said before the day's talks began.
Large countries like France, Germany and Britain, which embraced the double majority because of a worry about the risk of giving too much voting power to the smaller states, have also built measures into the constitution that would assure their continued influence.
Largely at British insistence, the states will retain veto rights over fiscal matters, leaving the door open to divisive issues like one that erupted recently over decisions by France and Germany, two of the largest nations, to run budget deficits that exceed limits governing the euro.
Veto rights will also be kept in matters of foreign and defense policy and changes to European treaties.
For the moment, other differences appear to have been overshadowed by the issue of voting weights. Some countries, including Poland, have in the past insisted that the preamble of the constitution evoke Europe's Christian heritage. The draft text refers to Europe's "cultural, religious and humanist heritages."
Mr. Featherstone, of the European Institute, said there was not a sense of immediate crisis if the states failed, "but there is a climate of ideas across Europe that something must be done."

HEADLINE: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: LOOKING SOUTH; 
With Endorsement, Gephardt Turns Focus to South Carolina

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS; Jodi Wilgoren contributed reporting for this article.

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Dec. 13 

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri took a celebratory jaunt across this state on Saturday, showing off an important endorsement and a campaign increasingly determined to build momentum beyond the state of Iowa.
 Mr. Gephardt's aides say he must win Iowa to have any hope of capturing the Democratic presidential nomination, and on Saturday he continued to pound away at his chief rival in that state, Howard Dean. But in recent months, he has also been carefully cultivating support elsewhere. Nowhere are those efforts more visible than in South Carolina, which will be the first Southern state to hold a primary next year. 
 This month, Mr. Gephardt started running two television advertisements here, his first outside of Iowa and New Hampshire. On Wednesday, he garnered the endorsement of Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina. Mr. Clyburn, a senior member of the Congressional Black Caucus and an influential political figure here, was courted by all nine Democratic candidates. 
African-Americans are expected to account for about half of the registered voters in the primary here, and Mr. Clyburn has been viewed as a critical ally in rallying those votes. He and Mr. Gephardt stood side by side on Saturday at the University of South Carolina Spartanburg and received a standing ovation from a predominantly black crowd.
"We're going to win!" Mr. Gephardt shouted. "We're going to have a new president. It all begins here!"
Though Senator John Edwards of North Carolina and Gen. Wesley K. Clark of Arkansas have been leading in most local polls, a significant percentage of voters remain undecided, and political experts say the endorsement will give Mr. Gephardt's candidacy a boost.
"It is the most valuable endorsement a candidate could get in South Carolina," Donald L. Fowler, a former national Democratic chairman and a South Carolinian, said of Mr. Clyburn's endorsement. But, he added, if Mr. Gephardt is "not in the race because of a poor showing in Iowa and New Hampshire, it won't make a big difference."
It was perhaps with Iowa in mind that Mr. Gephardt called on Dr. Dean to release all of the records documenting his dealings with Enron, the collapsed energy concern. He was responding to an article in The Boston Globe that described how, as Vermont's governor in the 1990's, Dr. Dean promoted tax incentives to get some corporations, including Enron, to set up insurance subsidiaries in the state.
"While Howard Dean was cutting taxes for companies like Enron and cutting spending on Medicaid, public education and prescription drugs for seniors, Bill Clinton and I proved you can balance the budget a different way," he said.
For the second day in a row, Dr. Dean dismissed the criticism from Mr. Gephardt, saying, "The Enron stuff was ridiculous." Flying from Des Moines to Atlanta, he told reporters: "Enron never got any tax breaks from Vermont. That is a joke."
The Enron subsidiary was one of hundreds of such "captive" insurance companies lured to Vermont with financial incentives. 
Dr. Dean's campaign manager, Joe Trippi, said in a statement that Dr. Dean had met with business leaders as governor, and that "building a strong economy was one of the things Vermonters elected him to do." 
As Mr. Gephardt tried to capitalize on Mr. Clyburn's endorsement, Dr. Dean added Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Congressional Black Caucus, and 17 Georgia lawmakers to a growing list of elected officials endorsing his campaign, buttressing his support among Southern and black politicians.
But Mr. Gephardt did not mention Dr. Dean to audiences here. He criticized trade deals with Mexico and China that have been blamed for job losses here and laced his speeches with a strong defense of affirmative action and a description of his life growing up in a poor family. 
"Jim Clyburn and many of you in this audience came up the same way we did," Mr. Gephardt said in Rock Hill. "We came up the hard way. That's why we fight for affirmative action. That's why we fight for equality of opportunity." 
Mr. Clyburn said he believed Mr. Gephardt's life story would resonate with voters.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Rearguard Protection; 
Presidents' Power to Polarize Gives Them a Winning Edge

BYLINE:  By SAM TANENHAUS; Sam Tanenhaus, a Vanity Fair contributing editor, is author of "Whittaker Chambers."

 BODY:
DEMOCRATS and Republicans agree that the coming campaign will be a referendum on the president's leadership -- "the direction in which his dramatic tax-cutting policies have guided the economy and the wisdom of his force-oriented activism in foreign affairs," as The New York Times summarized it. In addition, presidential advisers foresee a polarized electorate, divided along economic and ideological lines. The wild card is the Middle East, "the most explosive issue we face," one Republican said. "If we should take 20, 30 or 40 casualties there in one day, we'd be in very serious trouble," he worried. 
 Sound familiar? Actually, all those observations were made 20 years ago. The incumbent in question was not George W. Bush, but Ronald Reagan. In 1984, he was still being blamed by Democrats for a struggling economy and a poorly planned mission in Lebanon that had resulted the previous fall in the deaths of 241 American soldiers when their barracks was bombed. Meanwhile, Republicans staunchly backed him, especially the right. 
 Yet for all of Mr. Reagan's apparent vulnerability early on, he was re-elected with a record 49 states. Now it is President Bush who is portrayed as a divisive partisan figure attracting admiration and loathing in equal measure. 
Surely, there are differences this time around -- principally the Sept. 11 terror attacks and the war on terror, which have defined the Bush administration even more starkly than Mr. Reagan's cold war assertiveness and antigovernment views. Democratic presidential hopefuls are openly contemptuous of Mr. Bush. The angriest of them, Gov. Howard Dean, is leading the pack.
But if history is any guide, Mr. Bush's power to polarize may help him. Election results over the past four decades show that incumbents who have aroused intense partisan passions easily cinched a second term. Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton divided voters as much as Mr. Reagan did. Less divisive presidents, like Gerald Ford and George H.W. Bush, were sent packing. 
Partisanship helps incumbents frame issues in clear, simple themes. It also holds off challenges from within the incumbent's own party, usually from more partisan rivals. Since 1968, every incumbent who was challenged for renomination (or, as with Mr. Ford, nominated for the first time) lost. Those unopposed were re-elected. 
Elected in a landslide in 1964, Lyndon Johnson still seemed formidable in 1968. His popularity had sunk, but a majority supported the Vietnam War and his far-reaching social programs. But antiwar Democrats formed a "dump Johnson" movement, and Senator Eugene McCarthy came within seven percentage points of winning the New Hampshire primary. Three weeks later, Johnson announced he would not seek re-election, and a crowded field brawled in primaries that left the Democratic Party in tatters. 
Subsequent races followed a similar pattern: Mr. Ford's in 1976; Jimmy Carter's in 1980; and the elder Mr. Bush's in 1992. Each was forced to fend off a partisan rival during the nomination period. Mr. Ford, who took office after Nixon resigned, was praised across party lines for healing a post-Watergate nation. He was warned of an impending challenge from Mr. Reagan, but did not take it seriously. But Mr. Reagan was the leader of the Republican Party's conservative wing, which objected to Mr. Ford's centrism. A hard-fought string of primaries fractured the party in the spring and summer of 1976. When delegates assembled at the nominating convention in Kansas City, Mr. Ford squeaked through on the first ballot and invited Mr. Reagan to address the convention. Mr. Reagan endorsed not the nominee but the aggressively conservative platform Mr. Reagan's own forces had written. Mr. Ford left Kansas City as damaged goods. 
Four years later Mr. Carter's moralistic streak and hardening cold war stance alienated liberals, who backed Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the primaries. Mr. Carter prevailed but was upstaged at the convention by Senator Kennedy's ringing vow that "the dream will never die."
In 1992, George H.W. Bush turned off party loyalists by revoking his "no new taxes" pledge. He was challenged in the New Hampshire primary by Patrick Buchanan, who, like Mr. Reagan in 1976, gained control of the convention, which climaxed when Mr. Buchanan took to the podium to declare a "religious and cultural war" against the Democrats, all but dooming Mr. Bush's race.
More adroit presidents have used the politics of polarization to fortify their grip on the White House. Nixon limped into office in 1968 with only 43 percent of the vote, owing to a fierce third-party challenge by George Wallace. But he deftly drew the party faithful into his battle with the "liberal media" and the "Eastern establishment," and sided with construction workers who attacked antiwar protesters in New York. In 1972, no viable Republican challenged Nixon, and he trounced George McGovern. 
In 1992, Bill Clinton copied Nixon's model. He, too, captured only 43 percent of the vote, and his early stumbles cost him standing among Democrats and emboldened Republicans, who won control of the House in 1994, led by Newt Gingrich and his "Contract With America." But Mr. Gingrich's ceaseless attacks on White House "McGoverniks" helped Mr. Clinton reposition himself. Even as his policies grew more conservative (the overhaul of the welfare system was the most striking example) he was able to present himself as a bulwark against a surging tide on the right. This appealed to traditional liberal constituencies and pre-empted any bid from his left. The party's convention in 1996 was a coronation, and Mr. Clinton coasted to re-election. 
Mr. Bush's political team has absorbed these lessons. Their man, too, barely won the first time around and occupies the White House at a moment when the country is split. Yet he is content to be seen as polarizing by his foes. The Republicans' first advertising blitz implies that the administration's critics are undermining the "war on terror" -- an accusation likely to resurface in the months ahead. Also, like Mr. Reagan in 1984, Mr. Bush has been capitalizing on the economic recovery by reminding voters that the Democrats opposed his tax cuts. And he was quick to criticize the recent decision by a Massachusetts court endorsing gay marriage.
All this makes Democrats fume but pulls Republicans into his camp. It is already clear that no challenger will emerge from within, meaning that Mr. Bush, like Mr. Reagan 20 years before, can look ahead to November without squandering capital on a rearguard defense.

HEADLINE: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; 
Forget the South

BYLINE:  By Ryan Lizza

 BODY:
It has long been an article of faith among Democratic strategists that their party can't win the White House without at least part of the once-solidly-Democratic South. Since 1964, the only Democrats elected president have been Southerners, and conventional wisdom holds that only a Democrat with a Southern base can win the presidency. 
 Howard Dean courted controversy in October when he talked about the need for Democrats to win Southern votes. But privately, Dean's aides often make a different case. Al Gore's failing in 2000, they say, was not that he couldn't win in the South, but that he couldn't nail down New England. If Gore had been able to muster a few thousand more votes in New Hampshire, he would have won the presidency without a single Southern state. 
 For some Democrats, this insight has led to a heretical theory about next year's presidential election: Forget the South. The Forget-the-South argument has little to do with anti-Dixie bias. Instead, it is based on simple mathematics.
Consider the numbers. Democrats and Republicans agree that Bush and his eventual rival will each start the race with an ironclad base of states that are virtually unwinnable for the other party. Bush's base is rooted in the South, plains and interior West of the country, while the Democratic nominee can take for granted most of New England, the West Coast and a smattering of the Midwest. Most strategists calculate that Bush can count on 20 states with 170 electoral votes, and that the Democratic candidate starts with 11 states and the District of Columbia, totaling 168 electoral votes. That leaves the two candidates with a battleground of just 19 swing states.
Nine of those 19 states -- none of them in the South -- went for Clinton in 1992 and 1996 and for Gore in 2000. These are the blue-leaning states, and any Democratic candidate has to lock them up before dipping his toe below the Mason-Dixon line. Victory in all nine would increase the Democrat's total to 260 electoral votes, still 10 short of victory.
That leaves 10 red-leaning states, from which the Democratic nominee needs to scrape up those final 10 electoral votes. Four of them (Florida, Tennessee, Louisiana and Arkansas) are in the South. The six remaining battleground states (Ohio, Missouri, West Virginia, Arizona, Nevada and New Hampshire) are geographically situated in areas of the greatest Democratic growth and strength. Why, ask the proponents of the Forget-the-South strategy, waste millions of dollars fighting for the 27 electoral votes in Jeb Bush's Florida when you can wrap up the election by winning the 20 in the economically battered state of Ohio?
As for Tennessee, Louisiana and Arkansas, there is an argument to be made for the Democrats to fight hard in each of them, but they are less competitive than the swing states outside Dixie. This process of elimination leads inexorably to the Forget-the-South strategy. It also lets Democrats be Democrats. Instead of pandering to (as Howard Dean famously put it) "guys with Confederate flags in their pickup trucks," thus alienating blacks and liberals, a Democratic nominee like Dean could aim his message at Americans who might actually vote for him. Ryan Lizza

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Has Irrational Exuberance Hit China?

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: Hong Kong 

 BODY:
POWER plants in China cannot keep up with electricity demand, and so many steel mills are being built there that all the world's iron ore mines together may not be able to supply them adequately. Inflation, in the 12 months through November, ran at the fastest pace in six years, and the country's money supply is rising 20 percent a year.
 So what did China's leaders do last week? 
 Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said in Washington that China was not yet ready to let its currency, the yuan, rise against the dollar in foreign exchange. Economists say that this means speculative and foreign investments are likely to continue to pour into China. 
 In Beijing, the People's Bank of China reduced the interest rate it pays on bank reserves in excess of the legal minimums. That easing of monetary policy, partly reversing a tightening that took effect on Sept. 21, will give banks an incentive to lend even more money to companies and individuals.
 While China's leaders portray themselves as farsighted engineers who can manage their country's economic growth better than a democratically elected government could, their recent economic policies show a strong inclination to let the good times roll for now and to worry later about any ensuing bust.
 Prodding the money supply while resisting currency appreciation shows a reluctance to let economic growth falter at all, even as Western economists put China's expansion at an annual pace of 10 percent this fall. "If you're very preoccupied about social stability and you've got a weak banking system, do you really want to appreciate your currency?" said William Belchere, chief Asia economist at J.P. Morgan Chase.
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was accused in the late 1990's of letting the money supply grow too fast to accommodate American economic growth. Economists differ on how much this expansionary monetary policy aided the Internet boom and subsequent bust.
 But Mr. Greenspan's management of the American economy then seems downright stodgy compared with the conduct of China's rulers now. Indeed, Mr. Greenspan warned in a speech on Thursday of a possible overheating of China's economy, "with its potential recessionary consequences." 
 The official New China News Agency said on Wednesday that electricity consumption leaped 15.6 percent in the first nine months as factories opened and people bought more appliances. Blackouts are spreading: some businesses in Zhejiang Province have to operate in the wee hours of the morning.
 China's steel output is already up 15 percent this year, to an estimated 210 million tons, making China the world's largest steel producer and leaving shipping lines and iron ore mines worldwide working day and night.But Chinese provinces are already erecting additional steel mills with combined annual capacity of 120 million more tons. Even if iron ore can be found for these mills, China may have difficulty finding foreign markets for the steel.
 The common denominator in many of China's economic problems is a dysfunctional banking system that still extends some loans based on the political connections of borrowers, especially state-owned enterprises. At the same time, the executives of state-owned enterprises have shown a strong herd instinct of rushing into whatever industry seems to be growing fastest. A result is that many provinces build the same kind of factories at the same time, as is now the case with steel, and bank officers approve loans for most or all of the factories.
 LIANG HONG, an economist here for Goldman Sachs, said the decision by the People's Bank to reduce interest rates on excess bank reserves was best understood as a form of banking regulation. When the People's Bank raised reserve requirements on Sept. 21, it squeezed small banks, which had lent almost all the money they could and were holding minimal reserves at the central bank.
 The Big Four banks that already dominate Chinese finance had been more cautious and had ample excess reserves even after the minimum was raised to 7 percent of deposits, from 6 percent. But even with rates rising for interbank loans, the big banks have been reluctant to lend their excess reserves to smaller banks, which have been left so short of money to lend that they are being squeezed out of the banking market, Ms. Liang said.
 By paying less interest on excess reserves, the People's Bank is pushing the big banks to lend more money, especially to smaller banks. 
 But in trying to save the small banks, the People's Bank has sent the message that China's economic party can go rollicking on, at least in the short term. At a time when the Fed would probably be taking away the punch bowl, the People's Bank is letting China's people drink.

HEADLINE: A REGION INFLAMED: THE OCCUPATION; 
A Baghdad Neighborhood, Once Hopeful, Now Reels As Iraq's Turmoil Persists

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq 

 BODY:
Ghazalia is a neighborhood on edge.
 Random violence and roadside bombs aimed at American patrols make the streets unsafe after dark. On the local council, Shiites and Sunnis squabble. Jobs are scarce, and prices are soaring. The electricity fails daily, and cooking gas, a necessity here, has grown scarce. 
 In ways large and small, life in this neighborhood of 150,000 people has worsened in the eight months since the United States toppled Saddam Hussein. Now the residents of Ghazalia, a suburban neighborhood that is in many ways a microcosm of the city, are nearly out of patience. 
For the people who live here -- a mix of Sunni and Shiite Muslims, rich homeowners and poor renters -- the daily turmoil is exhausting and enervating. For the United States, it is a serious strategic problem, as was evident during dozens of visits to Ghazalia this fall.
To right its troubled occupation, the United States has focused on reducing attacks on American troops and capturing loyalists to Mr. Hussein. But a quieter battle is playing out on these streets, as American forces try to prove to Iraqis that they can police the neighborhoods streets and deliver basic services in a country ravaged by decades of dictatorship.
If the United States succeeds, it is in a position to dry up support for Mr. Hussein's guerrillas, who are more feared than loved. But if Washington fails, it could face a greater and new wave of resistance from ordinary Iraqis disgusted with their lives.
And so far, despite the best efforts of the American military, the United States is losing that battle, many residents say.
"It was very hard in Saddam's time," Jabaar Husan, 30, said as he waited in line for cylinders of cooking gas at 5:30 a.m. one day in November outside Ghazalia's propane station. "But life becomes harder to me and my children now, so I can't consider it better. The Americans did nothing for us. They just brought killing, theft, robberies, all those things."
Nothing symbolized the problems in Ghazalia this fall more than the shortage of cooking gas cylinders.
The lines formed each morning in the darkness at 3. By 5:30, with dawn approaching, more than 100 people waited outside the neighborhood bottling station. 
The men crowded around a fire, rubbing their hands and shivering in the cold November air. The women, in long black robes, stood in a row that ran crookedly between rolls of barbed wire. 
They had come for cylinders of liquid propane gas, used to heat ovens and bake bread. The cylinders were supposed to cost 250 Iraqi dinars -- 12.5 cents -- and in Mr. Hussein's time they did.
But now, the station ran out of gas every day, leaving the people in line empty-handed. Yet each day black marketeers in the neighborhood have plenty of cylinders available for 10 or 20 times the official price. And no one in authority, American or Iraqi, could explain why.
"Saddam sucked our blood," Ban Tariq, a mother of four, said inside her tidy home on a November afternoon in Ghazalia, just before the electricity failed yet again and the lights went out. "We expected after he was toppled that we would have our fortunes again, but we really got nothing. Each day we have a new crisis."
Ghazalia is on the western edge of Baghdad, sprawling and new, the most suburban part of a suburban city. It is surrounded by highways to the south and east, open fields to the west. A sewage canal marks its northern edge.
The neighborhood's most distinctive building is the giant Mother of All Battles Mosque, which Mr. Hussein built in 1999 to mark what he portrayed as his great victory in the first Persian Gulf war of 1991. At night, the lights of the mosque's minarets -- designed to resemble machine-gun turrets -- glare out.
Mr. Hussein began building Ghazalia in the early 1980's as a home for army officers and other members of his Baath Party. Concrete mansions with pillars and domes are common in the southern half of the district. More big houses, mostly unfinished, are scattered across a military base in central Ghazalia now used by American paratroopers.
But the big houses disappear near the sewage canal at the northern end, where children playing soccer share the dusty streets with goats, and the stench of human waste fills the air. Not coincidentally, northern Ghazalia is Shiite Muslim, while southern Ghazalia is mostly Sunni.
In Ghazalia, Mr. Hussein showed his contempt for the majority Shiites in ways large and small. He refused to allow them even one mosque, while the Sunnis had nearly a dozen. To worship, the Shiites had to cross an inconveniently located bridge over the sewage canal to Shula.
Abbass al-Musawi, a heavy man with a beard and a gray robe -- favored by many Iraqi men -- that makes him look something like a monochromatic Santa Claus, is not about to forget the insults. Mr. Musawi, a Shiite, heads the Ghazalia citizens' council, a group of 32 local leaders appointed by the United States to represent the district.
Mr. Musawi and his fellow Shiite council members ruled in early November that 18 former teachers, Sunnis who had been members of the Baath Party, could not have their jobs back. "We are frightened of the Baathists, so why are we giving them assistance?" he said. "They had 35 years. The priority should go to people who were unemployed before."
On the streets, the conflict played out more openly and bloodily this fall. On a Monday night in November, a white station wagon pulled up to a roadside cigarette stand owned by Shakir Muhammad, a former officer in Mr. Hussein's Mukhabarat. Three masked men hopped out and shot him dead. "His face was all in blood," said one witness, Abu Asad. "They targeted his face." 
Mr. Muhammad's funeral was filled with Baathists not afraid to defend the old government, as long as they did not have to give their names. "Everybody has his own pluses and minuses," said one mourner who identified himself only as Abu Omer, "Father of Omer." 
"Any ruler can make mistakes," he said. "Saddam Hussein is a human being, he was good. No one who was fair and just could deny this -- in agriculture, in industry, in trade."

Conflicting Views of Reality
On a television set in the corner, L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator of the occupation, was saying that United States needed time to root out the guerrillas opposing it. A few days earlier, the guerrillas had attacked three police stations and the Baghdad headquarters of the Red Cross, so this analysis did not strike Mr. Musawi as trenchant. Beside Mr. Bremer, Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, the American military commander in Iraq, wore his usual preoccupied expression. 
The holy month of Ramadan had just begun, and Mr. Musawi had invited two council members to break the fast at his home, a few blocks from the council headquarters. As Mr. Musawi disappeared into the kitchen, reappearing with sweet sticky dates and other appetizers, General Sanchez called the car bombs "an operationally insignificant surge" and Mr. Bremer promised success for the occupation.
The council members watched politely for few minutes, then lost interest. What did Mr. Bremer know of their reality? He never ventured out of his heavily protected compound without an enormous armed escort.
As the roasted chickens, tart yogurt milk and fried dough flowed out of the kitchen, the conversation turned to the once forbidden and still painful topic of the destruction that Mr. Hussein had caused in Iraq. The men joked grimly about senior officials who had barely graduated from elementary school and a science minister who did not know that steam is boiled water. 
To survive, Mr. Musawi said, Mr. Hussein turned Sunni against Shiite and neighbor against neighbor, creating networks of informants reaching into every block of Ghazalia. 
"I don't trust anybody, not even my close friends," Mr. Musawi said. Any gathering, even a funeral, could attract unwelcome attention. Tribes and clerics lost influence, and social organizations faded away, until only Mr. Hussein's government was left. 
Now the Baathists are attacking the basic institutions of civil society. Mr. Hussein's henchmen meant to leave Iraq with a choice between the fist of repression or the claw of anarchy. The United States needed to fight harder to stop them, and to recognize the cunning of its enemy, Mr. Musawi said. 
"Iraqis lie," he said. "The regime was dealing with the Iraqi people by force, the Iraqi people are built on force, used to being treated by force."
When they did approach American soldiers with important information about terrorist groups, the United States rarely acted, council members complained. Lt. Col. Eric Nantz, who controls much of western Baghdad from his base in Ghazalia, could not disagree more. 
"What I'm trying to do is get the locals to stand up," he said in early November, at the site of a rocket-propelled grenade attack that narrowly missed a Humvee filled with his soldiers. The attack had come in daylight, less than 100 yards from a school; the guerrillas escaped. "The overwhelming majority of Iraqis, they understand, but they're afraid," he added. "What we need is for them to stand up and say this is wrong." 
The United States cannot arrest every former Baathist in Ghazalia, said Maj. Paul Fellinger, the battalion's second-in-command. The battalion's officers tell local leaders, "If they're as bad as you say they are, we need sworn statements," he said. 
Colonel Nantz commands the First Battalion of the 325th Regiment of the 82nd Airborne Division, whose tanks and paratroopers patrol six neighborhoods, including Ghazalia. But the 82nd has only 800 soldiers to patrol a population of a half million. 
When the battalion arrived in May, it expected to be in Baghdad for a month, Major Fellinger said. Now the soldiers fear that even after they complete this tour in Iraq, they will have to return for another one.

A Family's Struggles
Things had not always been so miserable, Ban Tariq and her husband, Hatem Zaki, said. Ms. Tariq and Mr. Zaki, who lived with their four children in a tidy house a few blocks north of the barbershop, were Sunnis who had grown up in prosperous families. Carefully arranged middle-class furnishings filled their living room: a set of teacups and a milk pourer, doilies and glass bowls and matching wooden tables. But the family was slowly losing its grip. 
Last year, to make ends meet, Ms. Tariq had sold one of the family's two rugs for 250,000 Iraqi dinars -- $125. She and Mr. Zaki had received the rug in 1984, as a wedding present. 
"I told my husband we have to sell one," she said. "It's better for me to get new clothes for my children, better than to have a carpet on the floor of my house." 
Fearing armed robbers, Mr. Zaki quit his job as a cigarette distributor, the family's main source of income, and must pay higher costs for his diabetes medicines. He had not been able to find other work. The family gets by on about $125 a month, from his pension and what little Ms. Tariq earns from a small business making meat pastries for her neighbors.
The family is still wealthier than most Iraqis. But Ms. Tariq could not hide from herself the truth that her children's lives were worse than hers had been when she was young. She had traveled to Morocco and Turkey as a young woman. Growing up during the 1970's, she studied and played in peace. "We have other ideas for our future, but you want something and God wants something else," Ms. Tariq said.
Simply by staying alive, Mr. Hussein is damaging the occupation, people here say. The prospect, however remote, that he might return to power makes Iraqis afraid to cooperate with the United States.
The people of Ghazalia do not understand why the United States cannot be rid of him, any more than they understand why the United States cannot guarantee an affordable supply of gas cylinders. They wonder whether the United States is letting Mr. Hussein remain free so that its troops can permanently stay on Iraqi soil. Is America, perhaps, even working with The Destroyer?

Simmering Discontent
To the American ear, these musings may sound absurd. But after a generation of dictatorship, Iraqis believe the worst. As the days go by without improvement, the people of Ghazalia seem increasingly willing to believe that the only explanation for their plight is that the United States wants them to suffer.
That discontent has not translated into rebellion. For one thing no credible opposition leader has sprung up in the last seven months, though the Governing Council has little support, most of its members having lived outside Iraq during Mr. Hussein's rule, far from its brutality and poverty. Osama bin Laden's brand of fundamentalism also does not have much support in relatively secular Iraq.
The calm also seems to come from the fact that Iraqis are used to being ruled; before Mr. Hussein were the British, and before them, the Ottomans. So people wait and hope.
But hope is draining away, people say, and that makes them worry that the misery will curdle into anger, and into protests.
On a recent Friday night, 11 Shiites gathered for dinner at Mr. Musawi's house. All 11 said they were more pessimistic than they had been six months before. The United States is running out of time, said Muhammad Saddam. 
"If the situation lasts for the next six or seven months, the American administrators will feel like they're sitting on a big volcano," he said.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary 

BYLINE:  By Joe Rogers

 BODY:
DEAR DIARY:
Several years before relocating to Florida, I was commuting on the PATH to Hoboken and noticed passengers moving away from a section of the car. In a few moments it became clear that a good-size crab had escaped (from where?) and was looking for a hiding place.
 When everyone had disembarked in Hoboken -- and after a brief passing thought about a crab dinner -- I took pity on the creature. Using my newspaper, I scooped the crab up, carried it upstairs and dropped it over the railing into the river. 
 I was never quite sure if the lower Hudson would be hospitable to a misplaced crab, but it had to be better than riding the PATH.
 Clifford Reiss

Dear Diary:
Recently I was at Old Montefiore Cemetery in St. Albans, Queens, to pay my respects to my wonderful father, Ted. Since he is in the Shomrim section of the cemetery (where Jewish police personnel and their spouses are buried) only footstones are allowed.
As I approached, I noticed that he had a new "neighbor." I read the epitaph on the footstone, then read the epitaph on the next one as well.
I found myself smiling.
The husband, who died 10 years ago, had as his epitaph, "He did it his way." His wife, who was a new arrival, had as her epitaph, "She did it his way, too!"
How great to have kept your sense of humor even for after your death. As I drove away, I felt happy knowing that my dad was in good company. Dale Baskin Altman

Dear Diary:
One recent Friday evening, as I was fighting my way down the Great White Way through crowds of slow-moving tourists, I chanced to hear one of them remark, "Boy, they sure do light it up!"
His friend, in response, said, "They sure do." Then, after a pause, added, "But it's nothing compared to Vegas."
As a true native New Yorker, I wasn't sure whether to be amused or offended. Ellen Lask

Dear Diary:
After my mom died and we helped my dad relocate, I spent several weeks cleaning out, sorting and trying to let go of much of what my family had accumulated in more than 30 years in the second and last home we lived in together, in Peoria, Ill.
After giving it my best, I finally surrendered and hired two rather remarkable women to run an estate sale. I left them with some special requests -- items to watch for as they organized for the sale -- and they were careful to keep an eye out for things they thought the family might have overlooked.
A week or so after the estate sale, I opened a package expecting to see a favorite salt shaker and a set of toy dishes from the 60's that I was quite fond of. And there they were. But alongside them I was surprised to find another small box that, when opened, revealed a bird's nest that we had rescued as the winter set in more than 25 years earlier.
There are things that sit quietly for decades in a garage in the Midwest that are hard to situate in a New York City apartment. I was musing with my daughter about what we might do with it, thinking perhaps a friend's child or a nursery school might be the beneficiary of this treasure.
"Are you kidding?" said my very urban daughter. "Put it in a tree; that's like finding a furnished apartment." Elana Katz

Dear Diary:
We were living on West58th Street when our 23-year-old son died of a heat stroke/heart attack after a bike ride in Central Park on a hot autumn day. After that, I continued to walk past the Plaza Hotel and through Central Park on my way to work.
A doorman at the hotel, who knew I wasn't a guest there and to whom I was a total stranger, tipped his hat to me every day, smiled and said: "Good morning, Madam, how are you this morning? Beautiful day, today, isn't it? Have a wonderful day." He said it with feeling and genuine caring. His name was Edward Trinka.
I came to look forward to his greeting as if his wishing me a good day would make it possible. After about a year, I stopped one day and told him he couldn't possibly know how much his greetings meant to some people, and I told him my story. He was deeply touched, and from then on was even more careful to greet me.
Once as I was walked by, a small knot of people gathered to watch a celebrity get out of her limousine. Eddie rushed over to greet me, and the knot of people moved, too, certain that I must be Somebody. I laughed about that for a long time.
A little later, we moved to another place in the city, and I didn't see Eddie again. One recent Sunday, however, around the 13th anniversary of our son's death, my husband and I walked through Central Park and past the Plaza Hotel. Eddie rushed over to greet us and show us pictures of his grandchildren. He said that he hadn't worked a Sunday in 20 years but that he was working that day for someone who was ill.
Coincidence? My husband and I didn't think so. Peggy Sherertz

Dear Diary:
On the evening before the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, as I watched the inflation of the balloons on Central Park West, I overheard a boy of about 5 calling out the names of those balloon characters he recognized.
"What balloon is this, Daddy?" he asked, referring to the Uncle Sam balloon.
His father replied, "He's the one who Daddy pays his biggest check of the year to." Jeffrey Lefton Goldstein

HEADLINE: City Opera, In Flux, Is Changing Leadership 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
The chairman of New York City Opera, Irwin Schneiderman, a lawyer who has led the opera's efforts to leave Lincoln Center for ground zero, said on Friday that he would step down on Jan. 1 after 10 years in the post.
 He will be succeeded by Susan L. Baker, a former investment banker who is co-chairwoman of the board's strategic planning committee, which was formed recently to help chart the future of an opera company, founded partly by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia as "the people's opera." 
 With the company's location unsettled, Mr. Schneiderman said, the moment called for younger blood. He is 80; Ms. Baker is 53. "We're about to enter into a five-year project," he said, referring to City Opera's efforts to move to the former World Trade Center site. "So it seemed to me the leadership should be somebody who is going to be around to do it." 
Mr. Schneiderman is leaving at a crucial moment for City Opera, which desperately wants a home of its own, having shared the New York State Theater for 38 years with the New York City Ballet. The company has long complained that the theater was acoustically unfit for opera.
City Opera's proposal for ground zero is being evaluated -- along with those of 111 other cultural institutions -- by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts. The company said that it expected some indication of its chances by next month and a final answer by the spring.
Whatever City Opera does will shape the future of Lincoln Center, especially its ambitious redevelopment plans. If the opera were forced to stay, it would have to resume discussions with City Ballet about renovating the State Theater, talks that would probably be fraught because the ballet believes the theater, designed for dance, is fine as it is. If City Opera were to leave, Lincoln Center would need to fill the State Theater during the ballet's off-season. And City Opera, for its part, would still have to cover financial obligations on its Lincoln Center lease, which runs through 2014.
Another looming question is whether Lincoln Center would make a concerted effort to keep City Opera on campus, having almost lost the New York Philharmonic to Carnegie Hall in a proposed merger this year. Bruce Crawford, chairman of Lincoln Center, said his efforts had been only casual so far: "We really haven't done any more than express a desire that they stay."
That sentiment is a change from Mr. Crawford's position in May, a month before the Philharmonic merger was announced. "They don't want to be in the New York State Theater for reasons they have clearly stated," he said then. "They make a very good case for that."
On Friday Mr. Schneiderman said Lincoln Center still seemed indifferent about whether City Opera stayed or remained. "Frankly," he said, "I don't think Lincoln Center really cares much, which is fine."
When the Philharmonic was planning to leave for Carnegie Hall, Mr. Schneiderman and the opera's general and artistic director, Paul Kellogg, discussed with Lincoln Center the possibility of City Opera's moving into Avery Fisher Hall. "Lincoln Center wasn't interested," Mr. Schneiderman said. "They wanted that as a house for symphonic music, and they've already got an opera house," the Metropolitan Opera.
Mr. Schneiderman, whose law firm is Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, said he would remain on the board as chairman emeritus and stay on as co-chairman for a six-month transition period. "I have a great emotional stake in this company," he said. "We've been trying for a long time to get our own place. I'd love to see that under way."
As an investment banker, Ms. Baker worked at Goldman Sachs, Kidder Peabody, Lehman Brothers and elsewhere. Like Mr. Schneiderman, she has given more than $500,000 a year to City Opera, and she has been on the organization's board for four years. 
City Opera wants to stage 19 weeks of opera and 24 weeks of American musical theater each year in a performing arts center at the redeveloped World Trade Center site. Mr. Schneiderman said the opera company requested $100 million in government support for building the center, which is expected to cost $300 million. "We think, between gifts and bond issues, we can raise the other $200 million," Mr. Schneiderman said. 
Several arts executives have questioned City Opera's ability to raise that money. Robert W. Wilson, a substantial donor to the company, had initially said he might contribute $50 million toward a building, but later said he would not help subsidize an opera house downtown. "Based on the proposal they made, which would emphasize musicals as much as operas, I would not support it," Mr. Wilson said. "I think they should settle in and wait. Maybe in another 10 or 20 years another opportunity will present itself."
Even if he did contribute, Mr. Wilson said, it would not cover much. "I don't see how on earth the City Opera could come up with $300 million, even if I ponied up $50 million," he said.
Fund-raising for arts groups has been difficult despite the recent uptick in the economy; even the typically strong Metropolitan Opera had a projected deficit of about $10 million last year. City Opera had a $2.5 million deficit last year, and it is projecting a deficit of about $2 million for the current fiscal year, Mr. Kellogg said. 
The opera recently sought a line of credit to cover its expenses, to avoid dipping into its endowment. But City Opera maintains that is in solid financial shape, with an endowment of $57 million. "We are viable," Mr. Kellogg said. "We've got the reserves."
If City Opera is rejected for ground zero and tries to build somewhere else, Mr. Wilson said, the costs would be substantially greater. "To acquire land will cost at least half a billion dollars," he said. 
Another location being considered is the area around the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center if it were to be developed for the 2012 Olympics, which New York is vying for. Another site is around the Trump buildings along the Hudson River on the Upper West Side. But both locations are not on subway lines. And Mr. Schneiderman said City Opera's audience is "not the limousine crowd."
"We have to be near somewhere with very good public transportation," he said. "And that's not there now."
Mr. Schneiderman said he hoped to be involved with City Opera when it finally gets its own home. "It's the underdog," he said, comparing it with the Met. "I just love the whole notion of Mayor La Guardia and this being the people's opera. It's my kind of club."

HEADLINE: Another Battle For Bush 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
There are two things I hope will emerge from the capture of Saddam. Like so many others, I hope the effort in Iraq becomes much more widely shared, internationalized, which would be good not just for Iraq and the U.S. but for the short- and long-term stability of the entire planet.
 My second hope is that the Bush administration will begin to apply the kind of focus, energy and resources that it used in Iraq to the economic difficulties of ordinary working families here in America. 
 If you just went by recent headlines, you'd have the impression that the U.S. economy is as bright as the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center. The G.D.P. is surging. The stock market, retail sales and corporate profits are up. So is productivity. 
The front-page headline in The Daily News on Thursday said, "Santa Comes Early to Wall Street." It was accompanied by a photo of Philip Purcell, the chairman and C.E.O. of Morgan Stanley, who was described by The News as "the first titan to cash in at the end of a banner year."
The article cited several executives who were expected to receive year-end bonuses in the $12 million to $17 million range.
The Bush crowd will tell you that these economic goodies are bound to trickle down. Jobs will become plentiful. Pay envelopes will fatten. Nirvana is just around the corner. 
The problem with this scenario is that there are no facts to back it up. The closer you look at employment in this country, the more convinced you become that the condition of the ordinary worker is deteriorating, not improving.
The problem is that we are not creating many jobs, and the quality of those we are creating is, for the most part, not good. Job growth at the moment is about 80,000 per month, which is not even enough to cover the new workers entering the job market.
And when the Economic Policy Institute compared the average wage of industries that are creating jobs with those that are losing jobs, analysts found a big discrepancy. The jobs lost paid about $17 an hour, compared with $14.50 an hour for those being created.
The Bush administration and its corporate allies give the impression that they would welcome a big surge in employment that would raise the wages and quality of life for all working Americans and their families. But their policies tell an entirely different story. A fierce and bitter war -- not bloody like the war in Iraq, but a war just the same -- is being waged against American workers. And so far, at least, the Bush administration has been on the wrong side.
The war is being fought on several fronts. For example, after years of shipping manufacturing jobs out of the U.S. to absurdly low-wage venues, we are now also exporting increasing numbers of technical and professional jobs.
Another example: Despite the loss of more than two million jobs over the past three years, and the fact that nearly nine million Americans are officially unemployed, the Bush administration has refused to support a Christmastime extension of crucial unemployment benefits.
Worse, the administration is trying to implement a regulation that would deny overtime protection for more than eight million men and women.
Efforts to get an increase in the pathetic $5.15 minimum wage continue to fail. The benefits from productivity increases that have resulted primarily from an incredible squeeze that employers have put on workers are not being shared with workers. Health and pension benefits are in a downward spiral.
And so on.
The way to fight these and other abuses is for employees to organize. But the right of workers to form unions and bargain collectively has been under assault for years. A thriving specialty of the legal profession is the advice it gives to corporations about how to frustrate and intimidate (and fire when necessary) those impudent workers who want to form unions. That approach has been bolstered by the full force and power of the federal government, which puts struggling workers at a hopeless disadvantage.
A front-page headline in The Times on Dec. 6 said, "Employers Balk at New Hirings, Despite Growth."
That's the reality for workers. The corporations would like to hire as few people as possible, keep wages as low as possible, provide as few benefits as possible and work the workers as long and as hard as possible.
The president of the United States should be allied with working families in this struggle.

HEADLINE: With 'Sand and Fog,' Can Year Be Salvaged?; 
DreamWorks Still Looking for a Hit in '03

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
When the dark yet strangely beautiful directorial debut of Vadim Perelman, "House of Sand and Fog," opens Friday in theaters in Los Angeles and New York, many people in Hollywood predict it will offer something that the movie studio DreamWorks SKG has lacked lately: a critical success. Whether it can be a box office success depends on the reaction of audiences, but DreamWorks needs a winner. 
 This year has shaped up to be one of the studio's worst since the director Steven Spielberg, the animation executive Jeffrey Katzenberg and the music mogul David Geffen founded DreamWorks nearly a decade ago. Known for live-action blockbusters like 2000's "Gladiator" and arty fare like 1999's "American Beauty," the domestic box office take for all of DreamWork's movies so far this year is about $164 million -- or about the same as the take from DreamWorks' 2002 Christmas hit "Catch Me if You Can." 
 While every studio is subject to the whims of moviegoers, DreamWorks produces only 6 to 10 films a year, about half the number of its rivals. Things have simply not panned out this year. The closest it has come to a hit was the Will Ferrell comedy "Old School," released in February, and its box office total of $75 million is only middling by current standards. 
 By all accounts, DreamWorks has enough talent and creative energy to make larger competitors tremble. But its once-ambitious plan to be a powerhouse in music, television and film has faltered as the economics of those businesses changed. With the exception of the "Spin City" series, its television unit has never really taken off. And last month the company sold its music division to the Universal Music Group of Vivendi Universal for about $100 million.
 As a result, now, more than ever, DreamWorks operates in a netherworld of being too big to be considered merely a production company yet too small to be a major studio. And that has led many people in and outside of Hollywood to wonder if the company's disappointing year is indicative of bigger challenges facing DreamWorks.
 "They are creative people; if anyone could build a business model, hit a home run, they could do it," said Hal Vogel, a media analyst and author of "Entertainment Industry Economics." But as the movie business matures into a slow-growth industry, he said, DreamWorks is "struggling like everyone else."
 DreamWorks executives declined to comment for this article. But executives there have said the company is financially secure. In August 2002, it received $1.5 billion in financing arranged by bankers: $500 million as a revolving line of credit and the remaining $1 billion in an asset-backed instrument whose collateral is secured by future film revenues. 
 Furthermore, it is not until 2006 that Paul Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft and a DreamWorks investor, can start cashing in on his investment. And it is possible that if the animation division prospers next year with the release of "Shrek 2" and other animated fare, the unit could be spun off in an initial public offering as early as 2005, according to two people close to the company.
 Next year, too, could be a blockbuster year. DreamWorks is producing 10 live-action movies, including "Terminal," which is being directed by Mr. Spielberg and is to star Tom Hanks. Besides "Shrek 2," there will also be another animated film, "Shark Tale," featuring the voices of Will Smith and Robert De Niro.
 But the company's critics say the management structure of the live-action division plays a big role in DreamWorks' volatility. Although overseen by Mr. Spielberg, it is run largely by his longtime producing partner and friend, Walter F. Parkes. The two, colleagues say, are especially close, and Mr. Spielberg relies more on Mr. Parkes for movie advice than on his other partners, Mr. Geffen and Mr. Katzenberg.
 Mr. Parkes shares responsibility for picking movies with his wife and partner, Laurie MacDonald, as well as Mr. Spielberg. But the day-to-day operation of running the division is left to Michael De Luca, a young film executive whom Mr. Katzenberg hired from New Line Cinema in 2001.
 Mr. Parkes, though, has come under increasing criticism in recent months for being a micromanager who at heart is a producer, not an above-the-fray studio executive. Last year, he received a producer credit on five of DreamWorks' seven movies, an unusually high percentage of producing credits for a studio executive. 
 Outsiders say DreamWorks needs to do what other big studios do and acquire distribution rights to some other filmmakers' movies. "Until they shift gears and become buyers, it is a management challenge," said one executive who has worked with them.
 In September, Spyglass Entertainment ended a months-long production agreement to finance movies with DreamWorks even before the partnership got off the ground. According to one person involved, DreamWorks was slow to make decisions and did not plan to release enough movies to make it profitable for Spyglass. What is more, this person said, "it was confusing as to what the leadership roles were and who could develop projects." 
 Which leads to Mr. Parkes's relationship with Mr. De Luca. Mr. De Luca was hired to help increase the studio's output. But, according to colleagues of both men, Mr. Parkes and Mr. De Luca clashed from the start. One person who has worked with the two said Mr. De Luca bristled over what he saw as meddling by Mr. Parkes in his projects. That has led some producers to try and bypass Mr. De Luca altogether, knowing Mr. Parkes's ties to Mr. Spielberg, the person said.
 But Mr. De Luca's track record so far has been less than stellar, too. He was largely responsible for this year's underperformers, "Biker Boyz" and "Head of State," although Mr. Parkes ultimately approved the projects. Friends of Mr. De Luca say it is possible that he will leave the studio after his contract ends next year.
 Mr. De Luca did not return a telephone call seeking comment. Mr. Parkes, who was in the desert outside Los Angeles on the set of "The Terminal," declined to be interviewed by telephone.
 Mr. De Luca would not be the first to clash with Mr. Parkes. Bob Cooper, who had Mr. De Luca's job and worked on "American Beauty" while at DreamWorks in the late 1990's, also left after chasing under Mr. Parkes, said two former employees. 
 To be sure, Mr. Parkes can be demanding, but that does not always mean he is wrong. "I'm sure there are times when people have legitimate complaints," said Michael London, a producer of "House of Sand and Fog" who said he had a good working relationship with Mr. Parkes. "But other times, those people who have complained are wilting under the scrutiny of someone who is bright and creative."
 Supporters of DreamWorks say the recent criticism is just noise in the marketplace. The company said it has made 41 films (including partnerships) with a per-picture box-office average of $79 million. As a private company, it is not beholden to public shareholders who judge performance by a daily share price or quarterly returns. "It's an unusual set up, but it seems to work for them," said James Wiatt, president of the William Morris Agency. "It's their money and their philosophy."
 By reputation, Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Parkes would rather make movies they love even if that means making fewer of them. For better or worse, supporters say, it is a form of control not often exercised at large companies.
 "If you only make movies when you truly fall in love, you can only fall in love so many times a year," Mr. London said. "The challenge is can anyone fall in love enough times to really fill a slate?"
 Eager to put this year behind them, executives at DreamWorks have begun touting next year's offerings. 
 Billboards in Los Angeles promoting next summer's "Shrek 2" have been up for more than six months. Recently, a small group of journalists were bused out to the set of "The Terminal." 
 And in October, the studio held a poolside party at the W hotel in Westwood with the young stars of "Win a Date with Tad Hamilton!," five months before the film's scheduled release in March. And not to be forgotten during the holiday film festivities, early screenings of "Tad Hamilton" begin this week.

HEADLINE: Phone Service Over Internet Revives Talk Of Regulation 

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Politicians have worked hard to keep access to Internet connections and many forms of Internet communication free from regulation and taxation. But the debate over how government treats the Internet is likely to reach a new level of intensity now that Internet technology is colliding with one of the nation's most lucrative businesses, telephone service. 
 Last week AT&T and Time Warner Cable announced that they intended to make Internet-based phone service available to millions of consumers next year, allowing those consumers to bypass traditional phone companies. Those moves signaled the start of a technological shift that could change one of the biggest and most important industries in the American economy. Central to that shift is whether and how Internet phone service should be regulated, a question that the Federal Communications Commission started to explore in hearings two weeks ago. 
 In an interview on Thursday, Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the F.C.C., said he had not made up his mind on that question. But he was not at all shy about stating his preliminary view -- that Internet-based calls are fundamentally different from traditional phone calls and ought to be regulated cautiously, if at all.
 "There is no functional or technical difference between an Internet phone call and other data -- be it bits, or e-mail or Web pages," Mr. Powell said, during a visit to San Francisco. Up to now, Internet traffic has been essentially unregulated and untaxed because many politicians and regulators have argued that the technology and online commerce would grow more quickly if the Internet were left alone.
 Mr. Powell noted that while Internet-based calls might serve the same function as calls over conventional phone lines, the underlying technology was different enough that it would not make sense to subject them to "100 years of judgments" and regulations. "Let's get this thing right and define it as truer to its real nature," he said, referring to the new technology.
 His views are far from universally supported, given the many complex political and financial interests at stake. 
 What is clear is that the existing telephone infrastructure is heavily regulated, on both the state and federal levels, with intricate rules intended to keep phone access universally accessible and affordable. 
 Gene Kimmelman, the senior director for public policy at Consumers Union, said those regulations existed to satisfy important public policy concerns. He contended that goals like universal access would be gravely threatened if the world went to Internet-based services that were unregulated. 
 Mr. Kimmelman said that Mr. Powell's views, which seem to argue for far less regulation, would undo "social policy that has made phone service affordable and accessible." He added that one possible result was that basic connections which, under the regulatory structure were essentially subsidized by consumers and the industry, could cost significantly more than they did now. 
 Besides, he argued, function, rather than technology, should guide the regulatory decision. "It looks, smells, feels like plain old telephone service," he said of Internet service, and therefore it should be treated similarly. 
 This debate -- the latest front in a 20-year-old regulatory battle that started with the breakup of the Bell system -- will define the grounds on which various players in telecommunications compete. The question of how to regulate Internet-based calling will be "the communications regulatory issue over the next few years," said Eric Rabe, a spokesman for Verizon, with audible emphasis on the word "the."
 For starters, regulators will have to address some central technical questions. Telephone calls are traditionally carried to and from homes on copper lines, with routing of the traffic using circuit switch technology. Internet phone service digitizes voice signals and sends them as Internet data.
 Mr. Kimmelman argues that even with Internet-based service, the voice signals are still sent over existing communications networks, whether copper wires, coaxial cable or fiber optic lines. And he maintains that there is nothing sacrosanct about the mere fact that the signals are sent as Internet traffic.
 "It's just a different way of assembling ones and zeroes so they can be more efficiently transmitted," Mr. Kimmelman said, noting that Internet calls would still have to travel through traditional phone wires through part of their journey.
 Mr. Powell, however, maintains that what is important is not the wires but the technology involved. And, he pointed out, consumers who want to use Internet phones would still have to pay phone and cable companies to get Internet access through those networks, and in doing so, would still be supporting the basic telecommunications infrastructure. 
 "You pay Verizon $39.95" for high-speed access to the Internet, Mr. Powell said. He argued that once consumers have paid for that access, the providers should not necessarily be paid more for the use of that access to send particular communications, whether in the form of e-mail messages or phone calls. 
 Telephone and cable companies are staking out different positions, and other members of the F.C.C. may not share Mr. Powell's views. 
 The phone companies naturally are not eager to compete against Internet-based competitors who can avoid the huge costs of regulation. But some, like Verizon, also say that the solution is not to regulate Internet calling, but to deregulate the phone industry. 
 SBC, another major telephone provider, said it thinks it could compete against unregulated Internet-based services. The reason, said Dorothy Attwood, senior vice president for federal regulatory strategy at SBC, is that phone companies have a head start on features important to consumers like 911 service and the ability to make calls even when the power fails. 
 The cable companies have their own perspective on regulation. Atlanta-based Cox Communications, for instance, contends that regulation should be based, not on the technology used, but on the market share of a company, with larger companies subject to more regulations.
 Cox, which already offers phone service based on circuit switch technology to nearly one million customers, will start Internet-based phone service in Roanoke, Va., today. But it does not expect the regulatory questions to be answered soon.
 "It will be four to five years," said Carrington Phillip, vice president for regulatory affairs at Cox Communications, "before we have a good sense of how regulation is going to evolve."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Regulators Completing Settlement With Alliance
The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York attorney general's office are working out the final details of a settlement with Alliance Capital over improper trading in its mutual funds, senior people briefed on the negotiations said.
 The settlement could include a payment of as much as $250 million, some of which would go toward reimbursing investors harmed by the trading, these people said. It would also require Alliance to make certain governance changes in its funds. Page C2. 

Viacom's Blockbuster Problem
While Viacom has been talking with private equity firms about a possible sale of its 80 percent stake in Blockbuster, several people close to the company have said that no deal is imminent. At current stock levels, the market price for all of Blockbuster would be $3.5 billion -- about $3.2 billion in equity, with the balance in debt. Based on that valuation, a sale would bring about $2.5 billion in cash for Viacom. But that would generate less than the amount that Blockbuster is producing in earnings. As a result, Viacom's cash flow per share would fall, perhaps making its shares look too costly. Market Place. C9.

Black to Meet With S.E.C.
Conrad Black, the embattled chairman of the media company Hollinger International, will have his first interview with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Dec. 22 regarding questions over fees paid to him and his chief lieutenants. C2.

Some E-Tailers Struggle to Keep Up
So far in the holiday shopping season, a handful of the most popular online merchants have struggled to keep up with a stampede of traffic, according to a report by Keynote Systems, which tracks Web site performance. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C8.

A Network Needs a Bicycle
A teacher and his class at the Parsons School of Design have rigged bicycles with off-the-shelf networking gear, turning them into free wireless Internet access points using Wi-Fi technology. The bikes can connect to and amplify the signals of Wi-Fi transmitters, or they can tap into a cellular data network, allowing Internet access in places like subways. C4.

Chip Technology Resists Radiation
Researchers at an STMicroelectronics laboratory in France have developed a semiconductor memory technology that is immune to "soft errors" caused by background radiation, potentially eliminating an important barrier to shrinking the size of computer chips. C2.

U.S. Turns to India for Research
At an Intel plant in Bangalore, India, Ajith Prasad and 20 other engineers are designing and developing chips that they hope will power new types of high-speed broadband wireless technology. They are part of India's low-cost, deep pool of well-educated technical talent, a big draw for United States companies, which are increasing their reliance on research-and-development operations in India. C4.

An Appeal to Vote, but Verify
As the market for computerized voting equipment has intensified, critics have emerged, leading to demands that the new machines allow voters to verify their votes with a paper receipt or another method. New Economy. C4.

U.N. Meeting Calls for Study
Delegates to the United Nations conference on the Internet agreed that a group should be set up to examine whether to introduce more international oversight of the Internet's semiformal administrative bodies. C6.
